The details are really intricate, and there are so many cool little tricks... the way the elevator switches the pup around into his outfit, the telescope inserts, even the slide that puts him into his vehicle and then allows you to press down to launch the car away... my little guy was playing with this for what felt like hours, making little voices to act out a story in his head.
There are so many different aspects to it that inspire him to play, he can do it with a friend or just play in his imagination for a long time. It seems expensive until you realize how much is in this, it's a really high quality toy set!

title: A great set for outdoor play!
text:
This is a fun set of 6 colorful dodgeballs that comes with its own hand pump and carrying bag. A fun side effect of the carrying bag: My 12 year old daughter noticed that the balls inside resemble "the very hungry caterpillar" from the classic children's book!
Keep in mind these are the slightly smaller 9" sized balls, not the full sized dodgeballs that teens and adults would use to play. These are great for younger kids or games that work with smaller balls.

title: Spinning fidget toy, don't call it a gyroscope!
text:
I've got kids and we all love fidget toys. This is kind of an interesting concept for me, there's a couple of axis suspended inside of a half sphere and each can spin on its own direction. This makes for some pretty interesting movements, as you can technically spin one to sort of bleed the inertia off a different one and see the patterns of lines intersect each other. It's hard to explain, but kind of interesting to play with, as it makes you think a little bit about how spinning in one direction will effect spinning in the other.
It's made of plastic, doesn't seem particularly strong but not flimsy either. It's an interesting take on the fidget toy concept for someone who wants to try something new.
The only reason I'm removing a star is the description calls it a gyroscope. I actually LOVE gyroscopes because they teach about the balancing effects of centripetal forces. You don't really get that here, there isn't much to learn about forces and balance, I kind of wish it had that added perk. I was excited to try it but found it more like a traditional fidget spinning toy.

title: Simple and super fun
text: [[VIDEOID:be685d0d3133813d9411ee75dc178c4a]] For the price, this is great on its own or as part of a larger track. The obstacles are fun to hit and smash, my kids were having a blast trying to record it in slow motion and play it back (video included!). The box is pretty unique too, it can be stacked and connected as part of a track as well. I love it and would totally recommend it.

title: This is a ton of fun!
text: You know that game with the velcro (hook and loop) style ball and hand mitts that everyone had growing up? This is that game but played on your whole body! The attachment parts you wear are hilarious, a helmet, arm band, vest... literally try to hurl yourself at the fuzzy ball to catch it! At a recent family party we pulled it out and ended up having some of the older people picking up the kids and trying to wave them around to catch the balls like a mitt. Everyone loved it, honestly- I don't know how many times we'll actually play this, but the amount of laughter from that one evening alone was worth it. What a unique and fun game!

title: Not so bad budget speed cube
text: As cheap as the cube is, it really isn't that bad. The box comes with just the cube and instructions. The cube comes tight as usual and has a tension system to adjust the tightness. The turning is very fast however the bad corner cutting makes it hard to make use of the fast turning. As far as the build of the cube, it seems sturdy until the lightest drop slightly disconnects the pieces in the corners. Overall if you're serious about speedcubing, a couple of extra bucks can get you a high end speedcube, if you're not this isn't too bad.

title: Affordable, smooth, light, fast speed cube
text: Being just $40, the Tornado v3 M flagship is one of the best speed cubes on the market. The cube comes with some nice accessories including a nice travel bag and some customization tools. Out of the box the cube feels a bit tight but has a fully adjustable tension system to customize your cube to your liking. It also comes with a really good but simple magnetic adjustability system that tops the other ones I have tried. As far as the performance goes, the cube takes a bit of time to break in but after 5-10 solves the cube is good to go. What I like about the v3 compared to other cubes such as the Gan 12 is that it has an outer coating that makes it rarely slip even with sweaty hands. The cube is also lighter, quieter, and smoother than some other flagships I have. I have been using this cube a lot now and I recommend this to cubers of any level.

title: Lego set for engineering minds
text:
This is an excellent set, if not a bit more challenging than the average you might expect from Lego. I have to admit, with engineering in my family, I've always loved the Technics line- they're more of "the thinking person's Lego". Dare I say it, I might actually enjoy this as an adult more than my kids do.
It encourages exploration of mechanical ideas and designs, and you can tell a lot of thought and quality has gone into a lot of the details.
The pieces are somewhat specialized for the design included, but like all things Lego, the real fun can come from mixing it up and using it in other ways. I highly recommend this.

title: "Official Licensed Product"
text:
I was confused what all this stuff on the listing about "licensed" meant, but on the actual product when you get the box, it claims to be an Official Land Rover licensed product. It definitely LOOKS like a Land Rover and the logo is prominently displayed all over the place, but the listing feels very cheap-overseas in the description- it doesn't say anything about being an officially licensed brand name product anywhere here.
But don't let that stop you! Unlike some Power Wheels products my kids have owned, I LOVE that this has a remote control for parent override.
Unfortunately, it is very obviously a single seater once you see it in person- the box makes it look like there are two head rests, but there is in fact only room for one rear end in the seat, and the steering wheel is prominently placed in the center.
Otherwise, it is a lot of fun and has some pretty cool features (audio system? Yes please!). Would definitely recommend!

title: Best speedcube I have ever tried
text: The GAN 12 maglev has the smoothest and most accurate turning I have ever seen before. The magnets come a bit strong, and the cube a bit tight, but with its magnetic and tension settings, you can fully customize the cube to your personal liking. The maglev helps the cube turn fast with almost no friction at all, and the UV coating helps add grip to the cube so you don't drop it. So far I have been solving faster than usual with this cube and I really enjoy using it. The only downside to this cube is the price, but if you're willing to pay the 76$, I would very much recommend this product.

title: Such a great set for Harry Potter fans, very clever!
text: I was actually really impressed with how much detail and thought went into designing this set. The rooms, decorations, even the fireplaces which eject like trap doors (to sort of simulate how they are used as entrances) are really thought of and full of little details. This is one of those things that the more of a fan you are, the more little details you'll notice. My daughter picked on the fact that some of the lego faces which can be reversed to be different characters, actually have some connection to the person on each side. For example, our heroes reverse face are the people they turned into with Polyjuice potion in the story. I had completely forgotten those details in the story. This is just wonderfully creative and fun, another winner from Lego.

title: Really fun concept game!
text:
[[VIDEOID:c924220c7263f2c1e0c17ea4d90878bc]] This is a really clever way to make those classic laser-security system heist scenes come to life! You creatively place clamps around a play area to run a string, then set the timer "bomb" and have a certain amount of time to collect the cards and disable the bomb before it explodes.
Every time a string is accidentally moved, the timer loses time and beeps faster.
It's not so easy to get the trigger working properly at first, but after an evening of playing with it, we were able to get it set properly. It relies on a plastic tab blocking an LED sensor that moves when the string is pulled, and if the tab isn't placed exactly in the right position, the whole thing doesn't really work. I feel like it could be designed better to make that less tricky, but I'd imagine the game would cost more to produce.
An extra trick to make it more challenging: Have someone call out the cards in a particular order for the player to collect. This means the player might have to turn around and go back the way they came sometimes. Much more fun this way rather than just grabbing all the cards at once. Additional tip: Play the Mission Impossible theme on your phone!

title: Blast from the past for a new generation!
text:
We got this delivered this afternoon and I have to admit it has kept 3 kids busy from the moment they came home until bed time (with a break for dinner and homework).
My wife and I loved these as kids and I'm so happy to see this updated version back on the market for a new generation. It comes with gel pens which are considerably nicer than those I recall from the original set, and two plastic gear frames with different pattern smaller gears and stencils (although only one stand, so technically only one can be in use at a time, but don't put it past my kids to figure out how to hold the second one down to work in tandem). The look on their faces was priceless when they realized how it works. I remember that feeling, and seeing it on the next generation is worth every penny.

title: Good, but was expecting more from Moyu
text:
Usually Moyu makes high quality budget speed cubes that surprise me for the money. This one is good, but it doesn't feel like the same value I was expecting. In fact, it has one of the higher prices for a pyraminx.
The good news is that at least it seems high quality. Out of the box it turns great and fast, and comes set on the strongest magnetic setting. The tension and magnetic strength adjustability is one of the best I have seen. In the past I have had bad experiences with magnet adjusting, like the tip breaking off, or it just not working at all. However it worked fine, and I like that I can control the magnets since I like them stronger.
This pyraminx features the new Maglev system, which is supposed to reduce friction and feel faster, however it feels the same to me. So much so that I question if it is worth the money compared to cheaper alternatives. Overall if you like maglev try this out, if not, there are cheaper ones out there.

title: Such a good value for what you get
text: For only 12.99 I cannot recommend this more. As most Moyu speed cubes are, this cube feels, turns and acts like a normal flagship speedcube. The only difference is that this one is about half the price. The grip on the cube is amazing and really supports fast turning, and the magnets aren't too strong or too light so the cube isn't ever mis-aligned. Out of the box the cube came tensioned just the right way, requiring no setup. This cube is so good of a budget cube, that it shouldn't really be considered one just because of the price. I definitely recommend this cube for beginners and experts.

title: Really impressive speed cube
text: The RS4M is probably the best 4x4 for its price. Out of the box it felt a bit scratchy (as pretty much all speed-cubes do) so I applied lubricant and did a few solves until it broke in. I love the way this cube turns, with it rarely popping, I can turn extremely fast with almost no error. The corner cutting, and reverse corner cutting is phenomenal for a big cube as I can almost cut it right down the middle. The only problem I have is that the screwdriver for the spring adjustment system broke, aside from that I love the cube and definitely recommend this.

title: Great concept, a little delicate
text:
My son LOVES this toy. He wanted to bring it for show-and-tell because he can wear it around all day in school, and then take it out to drive around during recess.
The controls are pretty basic, you only get 2 buttons: forward and reverse/turn (those are the same movement). In other words, you don't get precise left/right movement, you can only go straight, or curve as you back up. I remember having plenty of RC cars like that when I was a kid, and its interesting to see my little guy figure out how to maneuver using those controls now. It's also got some pretty sweet LED lights on the bottom that not only look cool, but also remind you that you left the car on when finished playing.
The only problem, however, is the build quality of the car. My son thought it was broken the day after we got it because it would not respond to button presses anymore. Turns out one of the wheels got pinched by the body of the car and would refuse to turn. I had to pop the back out of the frame (basically removing the shell of the car) to get it to work again, and it was really difficult to get it to snap back in without breaking.
I managed to do it, but I feel like it's only a matter of time before it gets pinched and stuck again, and I wonder how many times I can do this before the plastic tab snaps off. For the price, even if you get a weekend of fun out of it, I'd say it is worth it. But I wish it wouldn't get stuck at all because he was very sad when it did.

title: Fragile remotes, lots of batteries, but fun
text:
I'm a little bit disappointed in this product, I used to love items from the Sharper Image and associate it with quality branding.
To be fair- I LOVE the concept, the cars are GREAT and a lot of fun to smash and reassemble. The downside is actually the remotes! The knob used to control the car steering broke on one of them the day we got it, the other knob broke a couple of days later. Didn't even last an entire week. We're talking, SNAP sound and bits of plastic feel out, and now it is really difficult to steer.
Meanwhile even when it worked fine, I was surprised at how many batteries this needs. 6 AAAs and 4 AA, not rechargeable battery packs like other RC cars I've owned.
Such a good concept, my kids LOVED it while it was working, but clearly this is a product with room for improvement.

title: Good, but a piece popped out.
text: Its a real shame because the cube turns so smoothly, it is lite, and it just feels great. But sadly a center piece popped out. Normally with bigger cubes that I have, if it pops I can get it back in. However I tried and tried until the piece that popped out snapped. The cube still feels pretty much the same but it looks off with a piece missing, and occasionally when I turn the layer with the missing piece, it misaligns and locks up.

title: Really fun tinkering toy
text:
This is an excellent little gadget if you like to tinker/mod/hack all the things. I'm a big tinkerer myself and my son has recently caught the bug (using his school calculator to play games and installing Android apps on a smartwatch that weren't supposed to work), so I had a feeling we'd really appreciate this.
The pros are pretty obvious- it's ADORABLY tiny, shockingly so at first, it's really fun and had a healthy library of developers/coders/tinkerers/etc already pushing it.
The cons are that it actually came with most of the stuff already on it that we wanted to play with, which takes away a little bit of the drive to connect it and side load. I'm not going to remove any stars for that, however, since I feel like most people actually would see this as a pro and not a con.
The buttons are kind of tiny and difficult to play comfortably sometimes, but once again- that's par for the course and expected for such a novelty device. Really a fun proof of concept and a great nerdy gift for the gadget junkie.

title: Good value, but could be better
text:
[[VIDEOID:f1d1ea39300d1d862512d490b12039c8]] I love Hot Wheels! And for the asking price, this is an incredible deal on not only one but TWO RC monster trucks from the brand!
Too good to be true, right?! Yes, a little.
While there are plenty of pros here, the bodies are really detailed scale models and really cool, there are some cons as well.
First of all, the batteries. It uses regular AA batteries in both the remote and the body. Each body needs 3 batteries, and 2 per remote, so that's a grand total of 5 AAs or 10 total needed for this set out of the box. Then there's the fact that the batteries are arranged in a way that is really difficult to reach inside when loading it up. Other RC toys we've played with have a rechargeable pack that MUCH easier to load, reload, charge, etc. This ate through our available supply of Alkaline AAs quickly and I really wish it was rechargeable like other RC toys.
But the most annoying part? The TIRES. They keep popping off the rim and then making the cars go slowly. I'll show in the attached video. You have to keep reseating them on the rim to continue playing. It happens far too often for a brand name product in my opinion. It's still a lot of fun and my kid likes it, but I associate Hot Wheels with quality toys and my expectations were higher.

title: Good kit but kind of limited
text:
My kids have recently shown interest in gems and geology, so they were super excited to try this out! This is a full kit, which means it comes with everything you need: Not only the tumbler parts, but also the various stage mixes and even the raw rocks to use!
I actually was hoping it was the sort of thing we could use more than once, learn how to use it with the included stuff and then do more of our own found rocks with the next batch! The thing is, it comes with only enough to do the included rocks, and you have to do them all at once if you want them to come out with the included materials. Beyond that, you can reuse the machine but you have to get more materials to put in with the rocks.
The machine also takes a LONG time. I knew tumbling was a process, but it's a few stages and each one takes a few days, so the whole thing took weeks of emptying out and putting in the next stage and setting the timer for the next set of days spinning. The entire process from start to finish was nearly a month. But, my kids loved it and it was a very educational experience. I wish it came with more DIY material, but I guess I'll have to find some more to do our own ones next!

title: Not really related to cubes at all, but cute game
text: The Rubik's name on this is purely marketing, let's get that out of the way. There's nothing about this game that has anything to do with a cube aside from the puzzle shapes looking reminiscent of the classic cube squares. Really, this is a generic puzzle game in which you race to build a complex shape from a card based on a set of pieces each player has. The pieces are made up of squares that look like a disassembled cube, but it could just as easily be Tetris-branded, Lego branded, or any other shape that one might associate with a popular name. It's a really fun game, my family really enjoys playing it, but my 2 kids who are speed-cube enthusiasts were a little disappointed it wasn't more closely related to the classic puzzle-cube.

title: Great for short term use, doesn't last long
text:
This was a lot of fun in the pool for the first couple of times we used it. But after that, we noticed it constantly needed to be filled up as the air did not last.
Eventually we decided it wasn't worth using as it needed almost constant reinflation, I think it isn't well suited to keep outside in the pool, it isn't very durable. And unless you take it down and put it away after every use to take care of it, it probably won't last long for you either.

title: Ok, but already had a piece fall out
text:
The more rows on a cube puzzle, the more complex the mechanism has to be. That's why I am actually pretty impressed at how smooth the movements are and how and how fast it is. It's also pretty light for a speed cube of this size and I like that it comes pre-lubricated (does not need to be adjusted like certain others upon arrival).

That being said, a piece did pop out within the first week of owning it, and it won't go back in. We didn't do anything abnormal to it, we've been using it like all our other speed cubes (my son is a competitive cuber and we own plenty of similar products). The asking price seems pretty standard for an entry level basic cube of this multiplier, so I'm disappointed that it did not last that long intact.

title: Good value for the price
text:
This is a decent 6x6 from a pretty good brand. My son is a competitive cuber, he's tried many brands and styles of speed cube, and this name has come up before.
Pros:
Comes pre-lubricated
Good value for the price (cheap for a 6x6!)
Light
Not too big

Cons-
A little tight out of the box
It locks up often (understandable for the price)

There are better ones out there but they'll cost you more.

title: Great pool fun!
text:
What happens when your pool ball accidentally gets knocked out of the pool?
You grab the other 5 it came with and keep playing, that's what! I love multi packs of things like this. We used to have only one or two balls to play with at a time, and every time someone would miss a catch or hit it too hard, we'd have to argue over who's going to get out of the pool to fetch it. With 6 total balls in this kit, I have no problem blowing them all up at once and throwing them in the pool at the same time. The kids have a blast with it. At the end of the season, you can easily deflate and store them.
Are they the highest quality pool / beach balls? I don't care, for the price you're getting good cheap fun with extras to spare!

title: It's an OK drone
text:
I've used a LOT of drones, from professional DJI models to the cheap pocket sized tiny drones. I love flying the little ones around the house and practicing zipping in between banisters and over bookcases, and I love flying my larger DJI Phantoms and Mavic outside for real shots of landscapes and aerial photography. I was hoping this would be a good in-between product.
It is not really.
It looks a lot like the Mavic Mini, but that immediately falls apart when you hold it and realize how cheap the construction is. That's ok, it costs about 1/3 of what I paid for my Mavic Mini. But I've held cheaper drones that felt better than this. The controls are very much like the cheaper smaller drones that have been around for years (including the flip feature, which is admittedly fun), and the quality of the camera has not improved since the first cheap one I tried 5-6 years ago. Find the most basic/free cell phone you can buy from a store shelf a few years ago and the camera quality will look better than this. That was ok back then, especially since I recall paying 40-60 dollars for those drones and the cheapest DJI was closer to 800! But now, I was expecting better. At this price tag and with 2022 tech, I was hoping it would be some sort of bridge-gap product.
The downside to being larger is that it sort of doesn't fit into either category... Unlike a more expensive drone with GPS and fine tuned motors, it does not handle itself well outdoors unless there is ZERO wind (nearly impossible, especially as you climb altitude), and it is too big to fly indoors without being in danger of hitting something and actually doing damage (unlike the smaller cheaper ones). I actually can't think of a situation that I'd like to use this with: I'd recommend a smaller camera drone to play with indoors and once you are approaching the triple digit dollar amount, I'd recommend even a used Mavic Mini for outdoor flying (much more stable with GPS, and a stabilized go-pro quality camera etc).
It does come with two batteries which is nice since they go quickly, and the carrying case is pretty nice too. I guess if you're in the market for a drone like this, it DOES work so it deserves at least 3 stars, but I'm slightly disappointed with what you get for the asking price.

title: Hot wheels and flying discs! WIN
text:
My 5 year old loves this accessory for our Hot Wheels! The car shoots down a track under this and hits a trigger that sends a spinning disc flying. What could be better? Just to clarify: The car does not fly! From the box my son sort of thought the car was going to to fly with this disc as a propeller on its back, like a helicopter car. Now I kind of want Hot Wheels to make THAT too!
But no, this is just something cool to add to your track creation for some extra motion and fun. The car will continue along the track towards whatever else you set up.

title: Fun but slow to charge
text:
This a cool water blaster that shoots really far and fast. Unlike something like a super soaker which requires a lot of manual pumping, this has a fully automatic battery operated system. Just pull the trigger and rapid-fire blast your friends with jets of water!
My kids had a blast playing with this however once the battery died, I thought it was done for. Taking the battery out was a pain thanks to the screw system, and plugging it in took forever to charge. My kids were playing outside with water and I thought maybe 30-45 min of charging would at least get it to turn on so I could blast someone as a joke before putting it back to fully charge... but no, I thought it was broken because it refused to turn on or do anything after charging for nearly an hour. Turns out I had to practically leave it charging overnight, the next day it worked fine again. I feel like this should have come with a spare battery to prevent the massive amount of down time between usage this has. Or at least given us the ability to use standard AA batteries or something. A proprietary battery pack that takes hours to charge really puts a hold on the fun.

title: Great graphics, alternative to puddle jumper
text:
My son has been learning to swim and hopefully won't need this for much longer, however I really like the concept of this swim shirt. It combines a puddle-jumper style swim vest with a sun blocking swim shirt for sensitive skin. My son usually wears both so it was really cool to have a single option that does it all.
The graphics are cute and fun, he loves the dino theme. The only problem is that the floaties are stuck to the shirt and can't be removed, which means as he's learning to swim and/or if we wants to take a break and take it off, the shirt has to come with it. That's ok and to be expected for the design, however we found it difficult to put back on if wet. Traditional puddle jumpers and swim vests go on easily with plastic clasps whether wet or dry, this zipper enclosure was much easier dry than while wet.
Other than that, it has been great!

title: Awesome stuff!
text:
If you've ever used a large bubble wand, you know how finicky it is to use without the right solution. While a small wand or bubble machine can sometimes get by with just dish soap and water, for the impressive bubbles you need the GOOD stuff.
This is that good stuff. I used it with the Uncle Bubble giant sword wand and it made some really awesome bubbles! If you're having trouble with cheap bubble solution, give this a shot!

title: Really fun- but makes a mess and gets stuck often
text:
This was great the first time we took it out, but it drips a LOT. More of the bubble solution ended up on our deck while trying to make bubbles than did in the bubbles. That also means you go through a lot of bubble solution right away. The included bottle will likely barely last the first time you play with it, so make sure you get a LOT of extra bubble soap!
Secondly, the mechanism kept getting stuck for us. Squeeze the trigger and the unit would try to open, but it was bent over itself. We would have to give it a little push with our fingers to get it moving again, only to have it get stuck again the next time we dipped it into the bubble solution.
That being said, it makes REALLY COOL bubbles when it works, and that alone is what you are paying for. I could easily be a 5 star product if it didn't get stuck so often and waste all our solution.

title: It's OK, but won't hold up to a lot.
text: We found this difficult to build, and even after assembly horribly unstable. The actual swing equipment is ok, I might hang them from a tree instead. The set is too short to play much on, it's cute looking but at best maybe one kid can climb on it and play alone. I wouldn't trust it with 2 or more. That makes it very limited use and honestly, your kid will probably outgrow it pretty quickly. I'd spend a little more on a more versatile swing set personally.

title: Decent cube, bad customization.
text:
When I got this cube I was under the impression that it would have good customizability, however that wasn't the case.

First of all, the magnetic adjustability system seemed good, but there were no instructions for it included. Eventually I figured it out and it seemed to work, but then the metal pieces to adjust the magnetic strength bent, thereby leaving half the cube stronger than the other.

As far as the cube itself goes, it's not that bad. It has a soft outer coating and a smooth feel when being turned. The corner cutting is great and the cube doesn't usually pop.

Overall the customization can be better but the cube itself is fine.

title: Cute and fun suggestions for bonding ideas, although some are more practical than others
text:
This is a cute set that makes a great gift. The cards have fun suggestions that range from heartwarming to downright silly, but sure to give a dad bonding moments with their kid. They are arranged in 3 categories, but some of them we found less practical. Especially since some of them seem to be geared towards a father and one child, whereas in my case there are 5 children in the home which can complicate some of the suggestions.
We found ourselves picking cards at random until we found one everyone wanted to do. But the ones we did do were a lot of fun. Some of them you do right on the spot, and others are more over-time sort of things. The latter is less exciting when you tell a kid to pick a card and they are excited about whatever it is going to be RIGHT NOW. For that reason I think it only deserves 4 stars, but it is still a fun product and cute gift.

title: The. Greatest. Backyard. Toy.
text:
[[VIDEOID:62c18ebc18329d4ddf4cad0d017523cb]] This is AMAZING. I would give this 10 stars if I could. I was thoroughly impressed with some other items I tried from this brand (Sunny & Fun), but this is the most complete and self contained, and most overall BLAST of all their products yet!
Not only are there 2 water slides, a side pool and a climbing wall, there's a bucket that fills with water above the wall that will SPLASH every 30 seconds onto whoever is climbing at the moment! If you've ever been to a big water park, you know how this goes! My kids were deliriously laughing from it, it's the best time we've had outside in a very long time. Even our neighbors with a swimming pool wanted to come over and use it! It's a little pricey and I'll be honest, I have a hard time folding it back up to fit in the box but it is VERY cool and totally worth it!

title: Fun for kids, a little odd with the Chinese stickers
text: This is fun for my kids to play outside as well as inside the house. The airplanes don't fly for incredible lengths, but the little ones enjoy shooting them across the yard and in the playroom (where they hit the walls). Thankfully the planes are Styrofoam and don't do any damage to the walls or furniture if hit. However, the one thing that I found odd is the stickers it comes with. The product description showed us funny stickers with catch phrases written in English, however the box we received was entirely in what appears to be Chinese. The stickers have what look like the same logos and cartoons, but all the text is illegible to us. There's nothing wrong with that, but it feels weird considering we weren't expecting that when we ordered this.

title: Pretty nice, once you break it in
text:
I've seen the plastic versions and heard that metal ones exist... but a wooden one? I had to try this one out.

If you've never used an infinity cube before, they're the latest in fun fidgety-toy types of thing, but also kind of more interesting because they bend and fold in ways that feel like it is constantly turning into something else. Sort like a transformer toy that goes on forever.

I really like the wood color and style of this, but my first impression wasn't very good. It was a lot harder to move and the wooden blocks would get stuck on each other as you bend and fold. Not anywhere near as smooth as the plastic variants. But the cords that hold this together just need some stretching to loosen them up. Once you've broken it in, it moves much more smoothly and eventually will give you the satisfying feel that an infinity cube is known for. I can't speak for the longevity of it yet, I am a little concerned that in the same way you need to break this in, it can also eventually stretch out and/or snap. But so far it's holding up and by then, I'm guessing a new fidget toy will be the latest craze.

title: Creative detail, but one part is a little odd
text:
[[VIDEOID:3d943acf8a623fc2f128e7a25a13c19a]] This is a really cool and creative toy- the construction vehicles assemble into a robot dino with some very clever bits, such as the bulldozer fronts bending like claws and the crane end acting like a tail. In addition, the ability to build the toy with the included screwdriver is fun and gives a sense of ownership and pride over the experience (you get to BUILD the toy!).

The only thing that's odd is that after all the parts are assembled, you can easily turn it into a robot and back with one exception- the caterpillar treads are supposed to act as legs and can't be removed/replaced without the screwdriver. You to need to remove 4 screws and put it in the right formation, and then replace them. I'd gladly give this 5 stars if not for that. But it's too cumbersome for my kid to transform it easily and therefore he loses interest in that bit fairly quickly.
But otherwise it is a solid toy with a lot of creativity.

title: Cool floating globe decoration, but hard to use
text:
My 12 year old daughter has this on her desk next to her bed, it's a really cool trick to see the globe magnetically levitate and will even spin if you give it a slight nudge. I recommend blowing on it to make it spin, because touching it is a gamble- this leads me to the next thing:
It is VERY temperamental.
It will float if you get it in exactly the right position and let it go, but if you disrupt it or nudge it too much, it will suddenly go off balance, jump and cling to the top very dramatically instead of float. For a younger kid this is very frustrating, taking my youngest several tries to get right. For an older child it should be fine, but it is not as easy as you would think. Also the on/off button is a touch area that doesn't seem to respond unless you tap it just right. Sometimes a long press does it, sometimes it only responds to a short tap, it seems very unpredictable.
It's a cute product, but I have seen similar ones with a switch instead of a touch button, and I would probably recommend one of those instead. The difficulty balancing is true of all these magnetic globes and just how it works, but at least you could have one that is easier to turn on and off.

title: Great lego compatible alternative, and each part is an individual set!
text: My kids love Lego bricks and this set is a treasure trove of compatible blocks in unique styles and shapes. The shuttle itself is really cool to build, but what really impressed me even more is the way each of separate included accessory came in its own sealed plastic bag. That made the instructions easier to follow, and actually helps delegate tasks between different kids ("I'm building this part!"). Really a solid experience for the price, I recommend it.

title: Nice bouncy area, smallish slide
text:
I recently got to try out another bounce water slide from this company that was bigger and offered a large slide, however the bounce house part was not large enough if kids just want to jump around.
This product is the opposite- the bounce area is nearly double the size, so more kids can jump at a time if they like the trampoline-style part of the toy more. However the slide part is a fraction of the height of the other one, so the slide is not quite as enticing, especially without a pool at the bottom.
If you want this one, I would recommend a wading pool or similar that the slide would go into at the bottom, but I can tell you that the taller slide version with a smaller bounce part was the more popular of the two models when we tested them here. It is more expensive as well so keep that in mind- this product is a little cheaper and actually really good if you are more limited in space and want a larger jumping area.

It comes with a storage bag and motor with a generous length of power cord. Personally, I found the storage bag to be somewhat silly as there's no way I can get it to fit back in there!

title: Lumpy and not round
text:
These are cute and fun for mini hoops and indoor play as well as outdoors, but I can't give it more than 2 stars. I pumped it up and found them all to be somewhat lopsided with a permanent crease from the packaging. I pumped it up and left it for days to stretch, and even tried pumping it again afterwards but the crease is still perpetually there. That means it not only looks weird, the line prevents it from bouncing correctly if you dribble on the floor.
A basketball that isn't even round and can't dribble isn't a basketball at all, mini sized or otherwise.

title: Fun, yet difficult with truly competitive people
text:
This is a very simple yet very fun game to play with a large family- as long as they don't get too competitive about it. I love that the description cards make for very unexpected combinations that can bring out very creative out-of-the-box thinking interpretations. HOWEVER, this can also be the downside to the game as those interpretations can get pretty vague.
What happens in a group of very creative yet very competitive family members, is we begin fighting over what counts or not.
For example, if one of the cards says "can be used for decoration", and a player demonstrates that a blanket can be used as sash to dress up an outfit, the other players start arguing it doesn't count and we end up submitting to a vote. Of course, the player who voted NO also has a questionable item: "can be used to write", brought their little brother who is learning how to write his name and spell simple words. The undeniably funny creative answer is awesome, but then the players can't agree on whether it counts or not. We almost stopped the game after the first few rounds because some of the older players were arguing after EVERY round.
Once we all finally agreed to be willing to give up on a contested item (look, you can't fight to get every single card point every single time, the game is boring if we all score all the points on all the rounds!), the game actually got a lot more interesting and fun. If you go into this with an extremely competitive mentality, it will quickly lose its charm as you try to argue every description. However, if you come into this with a healthy dose of humor and creative thinking, and understand that sometimes we'll get a kick out of the answer even if you don't win the point, it's a LOT of fun for the whole family!

title: Difficult to get them going
text:
I remember Beyblades being a thing about 20 years ago and thinking it was super cool. Now, my kids are old enough to appreciate them so I was excited to try this starter set with them. Well, truth be told, I remember them being easier to click and start up. This set comes with everything you need, but my kids found it difficult to pull the cord and get them going without the blade falling off the launcher. It doesn't seem to want to stay in place. It could be that they were always like this, but I don't remember it being so frustrating.

My kids eventually got it going and are enjoying it, and I really like the arena and entire blast from the past that this elicits. Maybe my expectations were unrealistically based on nostalgia, but I remember this being better built back in the day.

title: Fun for a group setting
text: There's a lot of fun activities and items in this package. My kids enjoyed playing the inflatable ear ring toss game especially, as well as the sack races. The items aren't super high quality, but they are fun and for the money it's a pretty great value in my opinion!

title: Impressive pool size, super backyard fun!
text:
I've had some experience with inflatable bouncy houses before, and had the opportunity to try two offerings from this brand.
This one is clearly the superior of the two, with a taller climbing area and dual slide, but the clincher is a large diameter pool area at the bottom! It's not hot enough here to have turned on the water yet, but my son and his friends had a great time playing in the yard, and the taller climbing wall made it more of a hit over the other bouncy house which actually offered a larger bounce area.
It comes with everything you'd need, including a motor with a very generous extension cord (my old motor from a previous set had a very short cable and required a long extension cord), stakes to hold it down and patch kits, etc.
It even has a carrying bag to put it in, however this is the one caveat... When you are done playing, this thing is HUGE and HEAVY! It's also nearly impossible to get it back into the bag unless you have extreme patience and a lot of strength to keep lifting and folding and shoving. I ended up finding some over sized lawn contractor bags and wrapping it from both sides and storing it in the shed. I'd consider the bag pretty much useless personally, but maybe other people would have more luck. Make sure you have adequate space to store it, it's really quite large! Otherwise, this is a ton of fun and I can't wait for summer to attach the water line!

title: Must have for fans of the show!
text: My 5 year old is a huge fan of Spidey and his Amazing friends. We have some Marvel toys around the house that he's played with before, but he doesn't know Spider-Man from the comics/MCU as much as this variation. So as you can imagine, he was over the moon with excitement when he saw this set! They aren't fully posable, however their arms do move which makes it fun for web shooting pose, and they are actually quite tall- much more so than the average action figure. Build quality is pretty nice too, these seem like pretty high quality and really fun to play with.

title: These are GREAT! But careful of the cleanup!
text:
These are impressive for the size- They're not quite a full-sized confetti canon, but I did NOT expect these to be as grand as they are! We used them at a bat mitzvah to shower the girl with confetti after her speech and it got confetti EVERYWHERE! And I mean everywhere- we were picking it out of the food. So be careful shooting this around open buffets!
It makes a very satisfying pop when going off, sounds almost like a gunshot. Great to surprise someone who isn't expecting to be showered with multi-colored flecks of happiness. But I spent a good portion of the next day cleaning up the debris, and I'm still finding some pieces hidden in corners. I love how portable they are too, but make sure you watch the video re: how to use it first to make sure it works on the first try. I got it working the first time, but I gave it to some girls to use and they couldn't get it to fire until the second or third attempt.
I really like this product for adding some extra festivity to a party!

title: Fast and controllable
text:
Most speedcubes at this price usually aren't fast or controllable. This one however, nailed both speed and control. This cube can simultaneously be fast, and not overshoot or lock-up. I also love the smooth feel and grip on the cube, it really enhances the control aspect by not slipping.
However there are some minor cons for this:
-The cube can at times make a creaking noise when turned really slowly.
-The customizability for this cube isn't the greatest.

Overall this is a great cube for the price, I definitely recommend it. However if you are looking for a bit of a faster variant of this, for a couple dollars more you can get a maglev version of this.

title: Amazing graphics, but not smooth for cardistry
text:
I have collected many different types of cards for playing and tricks. The design on these struck my interest, but aside from that design I feel like these could be better for the price.

Some pros for these cards are:
- The deck comes with a double sided card which can be handy for magic tricks
- I really love the design and retro-theme, there are even little surprises in the details (for example on certain cards there is a little spaceship hiding firing at the number)
Some cons are:
-The cards don't feel smooth
- They bend easily
- They don't spread too easily
- Not good for cardistry or physical tricks
For the money I definitely think they could have done better with the quality, and they could have used air cushion finish or something smoother. But they are OK for playing- as long as you don't expect to do any cool shuffles or physical tricks, these are a decent value.

title: Mini Nerf shooters!
text: We have full sized Nerf guns that I use with my kids on summer days outside. But what's amazing here is that these are mini sized, you can hide them under a jacket or strategically around the yard for a surprise attack! I love how much smaller these are, and while you shouldn't expect Nerf-brand quality, for the price you get a LOT of shooters and a really good time right out of the box. I love it!

title: High speed fun!
text: It's actually a little bit difficult to understand what this set does from the listing, and the instructions were difficult for my kids to follow without my help. However, once you have it assembled, it's a TON of fun to see the car loop and jump to the target! These are great pieces for additional hot wheel tracks as well- unlike some stunt kits which really focus on a single use, there are lots of very easily repurposed track parts here. Makes a great gift for any enthusiast for that reason, both additional track parts and a self contained stunt. But I wish the instructions were a little simpler for my kids to follow. They've built other tracks without my help so I was surprised they needed it for this one.

title: Alternative and compatible with LEGO!
text: YES, these WILL work with Legos! If you want some extra bricks that won't break the bank, you can't go wrong with these! You get a three pack of different style kits, but of course you can mix and match and build whatever you'd like. It's nice that they come individually wrapped so you can use them as 3 gifts for 3 different kids if you want, or save them as 3 different prizes. They are 100% compatible with Legos and at this price, they are a total bargain!

title: Great party favor, but breaks easily
text:
The good news is that they are fun, feel good, and come in a big pack which excited the kids.
They are great for slinging, and can sling pretty far. We used them for prizes at my son's 5th birthday party, and they were a hit.

The bad news is that you need a pack of this quantity because they very easily internally pop. No mess, it seems to be contained in the inside, but they pop and deflate so the kids will ask for a new one. Thankfully we had plenty of extras, but that's something to keep in mind.

title: Great for a party of 16 kids, not all balloons are themed.
text:
For the asking price, this is a pretty convenient kit that includes almost everything you'd need for a kid's party. Plates, cups, napkins, a cake topper, table cloth, banner... all with the Monster Truck theme. My 5 year old son was delighted by it all. All you need to do is add some activities (pin the wheel on the truck was a fun one) and food! Oh, and a helium tank. And that's where this product loses a star in my opinion... see, the balloons are something we were excited about, but it turns out there's only one real truck balloon, 2 checkered flag ones (which are theme matching only by proximity to the truck, otherwise they aren't obviously race flags) and then a bunch of just generic balloons with no print at all on them. We bought a helium tank to inflate all of the above, which comes with its own set of balloons. I was a little bit disappointed because this kit says it comes with 18 balloons, but really only 3 are themed (well, really only one, the other two sort of phone it in). The other 15 balloons are just generic colors, much like the kind that comes with the tank anyway. When you see 18 balloons advertised in a themed party kit, you'd at least expect them to have a picture printed on them or something? We didn't even use the other 15 since the ones that come with the tank were plentiful and easier to blow up.
It's still a good product and worth the money, but beware that the balloons might not be what you think.

title: Great for goodie bags and prizes
text: The strength of this product is that there are a LOT. You're not going to get 30 completely unique vehicles, and they are not going to be the highest quality or durability, but they will be exciting to get as a gift or prize to a small child. And if one breaks, you'll have a spare to give them. I have a son who just turned 5 and prizes like these were perfect to use for mini games and goodie bags. The kids loved playing with them. For the price, I'd say these are a great deal and would recommend them!

title: Lots of bubbles! And even better: Rechargeable!
text:
Used this for my son's 5th birthday party this past weekend, and I gotta say I love it! Not only is the spaceship fun looking, but unlike our last bubble machine which ate through batteries (and got them corroded when we left them inside eventually throwing it away), this comes with a rechargeable battery pack! The battery uses a standard USB port to charge, and looks similar to many Chinese RC toy equipment battery packs.
You need to wait about 15 seconds for the bubble solution to make its way to the wands, so it doesn't start instantly. But once it gets going, it's a ton of fun! Bubbles were flying all over the place in no time!
The only caveat is the rechargeable battery is not all that large and seems to only last about 1-1.5 hours. The party was about 2 hours long, and after going inside for some cake in the middle, we came out to find the battery had died and needed recharging. The good news is that it didn't take very long to charge back up, but that's something to be aware of if you want this running for a long time to set the mood at a backyard shindig.

title: Great for tinker-kids!
text:
My son has been asking me to get him a "drill screwdriver for kids" after wanting to help me out around the house. At 4 years old, I'm not ready to let him play with my real power tools, but giving him a toy screwdriver won't cut it because it, to quote him, "doesn't actually do anything".
Enter this toy set to save the day! How can you get any better than dinosaur themed toys that you build with an electric screwdriver? He loves it because he can put it together and take it apart and show his friends his "tools". The actual toys could be a little bit better quality, but the point is mostly that he can build it and have a sense of pride in what he made!

title: Really imaginative and pretty fun
text:
We've owned plenty of hotwheels sets, some pretty standard and some pretty creative. This is one of those interesting ones I couldn't really understand until we got it. The car is sort of on an "assisted loop", in that there are points that require your intervention to continue. It starts off being "spit out" by the dragon, then fired from a booth, then launched up a loop, and- if everything goes according to plan - it lands on the head of the dragon which will either fall forward or to the side (not knowing which way is part of the fun). However, if you don't have everything 100% seated properly, it just fails miserably. My kids had trouble getting it to work until I came and reseated some parts more forcefully, but even then we still had a few misfires that caused it not to work.
But I suppose that's the tradeoff of the more obscure track sets, sometimes they are more difficult to operate successfully. Part of the fun is making it work, I think. But if you have a kid who isn't up for that challenge, maybe this isn't the set for them. We actually really liked it, and the payoff when it DOES work is the sort of moment that gets high fives and cheers all around.

title: My son likes it and that's what matters
text:
This is a cute set for fans of Disney / Pixar, we loved the Cars movies and my son is a big fan of hotwheels and similar track sets, so this seemed like a good match!
However the track seems to be somewhat inconsistent in working. Sometimes the car gets stuck or doesn't go where you want it to, and it's just disappointing for me when that happens. I expected more from a product that Disney allowed its brand to appear on, however none of this appears to keep my son from enjoying it immensely. I guess I can't complain too much since ultimately, if HE enjoys playing with it, that's the purpose of the set in the first place. So, 4 stars for being a good toy. I also really love that the case is part of the track, and the parts can be stored inside. I wish all track sets did that.

title: Difficult to build but the kids love it
text:
I opted for the 6' version, which is plenty large for my 4 year old and his friends to climb and play on, but honestly I kind of wish I gotten the larger 10' version. Pictured here is my 9 year old daughter, who can sit on the top easily enough but it is not really fun to climb the smaller one at her height. The plus side is that it can actually fit inside our living room if we had opted to have some indoor climbing fun during the cold winter or rainy days. Construction is pretty solid once you have it all together, however the instructions are pretty terrible and difficult to follow. Not only that, but this is NOT something I could have done myself. My kids helped me, and we had to build it over the course of 2 days. To be fair, we did have to quit the first day because it was getting cold and rainy, but we would probably have called it quits by then for the day either way because it was getting late and taking longer than I expected. You need someone to hold the pieces in place while you tighten the nuts, which often made me feel like I needed at least 3 arms if not 4. If I were building it myself I probably would have given up.
BUT... once it is assembled? It's everything I wanted it to be. My kid is happy, my older kids want the bigger one now.

title: Family fun that can include the youngest players
text:
I wish I could give this more than 5 stars. My little 4 year old is always jealous of his older siblings' board games, he often pretends he can play or asks "to be on a team" so he can be part of the fun. But with this, he can actually play unassisted! The game is simple, it's charades but no reading is required. Each card is just a picture, and it is up to the player's interpretation to act out. For example, if a kid doesn't know the difference between a crossing guard and a police officer, that's fine! Whatever word they think it was, they act out and everyone else guesses! There are no wrong ways to interpret it, so any child with an imagination can play!
He loves this game so much, we even took it recently on a trip to visit his grandparents. If you have a child who is too young to play games that require reading, this is an absolute treasure. I can't believe it took this long for someone to realize the market potential for this. LOVE it!

title: Basically the Newlywed game in a box!
text:
If you've ever played or seen the Newlywed game, this should be familiar. Players get a small dry-erase board with markers and eraser, and a card is drawn with a question. The players have to write their answer and reveal them at the same time. Depending on the question, answers have to either match, call out the other player, or be more creative than the other.
The rules aren't clear since points aren't really awarded, and who's to say which answer is more creative for those cards... but winning or losing is not the point of this game- the point is to have FUN! And fun it definitely is! My wife and I played for a long time and really found ourselves laughing out loud.
I'd imagine this game will adapt to the players- if you want a squeaky clean family friendly game, the answers can be totally safe, or if you'd rather answer them in NSFW ways you can choose to. The interpretation of the answer is totally up to the players.

title: Some quirks, but the classic experience is in there
text:
[[VIDEOID:98c98e0930a4d0d55067b255c77f0092]] UPDATE: It does not seem that you can load your own roms. Also, it seems the language selection is only for the menu, the ROMs are the same and that means titles that aren't English won't be no matter what. Super Mario Bros 3 for example, has the text bubbles from Toad at the end of each world in what appears to be Japanese. I'm guessing this file is a rip from the Japanese cartridge. I tried connecting the device to a computer to see if I can access to the storage and perhaps update it in case they are standard NES rom files (and maybe remove the homebrew roms that we aren't interested in to keep the list manageable). No luck. I found a video teardown on Youtube to see if maybe there is a hidden storage card inside or something. Nothing. It's an OK game player if you have some games available that you actually want to play, but for the money I know there are others that are better and actually let you update what games you want/don't want (and add others if you have access to them).

Original Review:
I tried one of these handhelds once before and was very disappointed in the lineup. Like that one, this claims hundreds of classic games, but a lot of them you've never heard of. In fact, many of them appear to mostly be weird knock offs or duplicate / slightly modified versions of games you have heard of.

That being said, the classics I wanted ARE here! The original NES Mario trilogy is here and can still be played with mostly muscle memory from 30+ years ago! I even introduced some of my kids to my favorite, Super Mario Bros 3, and had all the nostalgia watching them play too. Unfortunately there's also Super Mario 4, 5, 6 and a bunch of other bizarre titles that seems like hacks of existing games with minor modifications. In the rom community, these are often referred to as Homebrew titles. It's a shame that there's so many more of those than real released games to choose from, clogging up the game selection. If you didn't know it wasn't an actual title release, you might be confused as to what is a real game in here.
In fact, even the "real" games seem slightly off. For example, the original Super Mario Bros has music that plays noticeable too fast. Like the game is on speed. Weird.
There are other games I used to own that are not on here, I'm actually wondering if I can modify the storage and put my own NES roms in and take out the weird hack ones, but I haven't been able to pry it away from my kids long enough to experiment with it. I guess that's a good thing, I have to admit I am enjoying this product much more than I expected to. Much better than the last handheld classic player I tried.

title: Careful not to break plastic parts
text:
[[VIDEOID:1cd5e79c4addc5ad18346acf9e0ec2cb]] This is a fun set, and oddly enough we found out it is compatible with another similar looping train set from a different brand!
What's better about this one, aside from the dinosaur theme and extra parts, is that the batteries are rechargeable packs instead of eating up AAA batteries. The tracks are a little trick to take apart after play time is over, however. The first time we tried to clean it up, we actually broke the plastic tab that holds the track together on a piece. Almost broke another one before we realized you have to be careful and sort of twist a little to get them to come apart. Be careful with that. Could use better instructions. But a fun toy regardless.

title: Really fun train set- Oddly compatible with another brand?
text:
[[VIDEOID:59154a7e8beef889c0df1fa7d6e53a50]] This is a cool toy- an electric train that does loops thanks to a track with gears / sprockets. It's actually a pretty cool set and fun to watch the train go upside down. Make sure you have AAA batteries for it, I was disappointed it didn't use rechargeable or at least the more common AA instead, but no matter- the train is fun!
Interesting tidbt: the set appears to be Dino-themed, but only in passing. The tagline on box says something about the past, and the signs on the station reference dinosaurs, but otherwise it appears to be just a train set with no other mention or reference to dinosaurs. However, a similar train set that we got a month or two earlier IS dinosaur themed, made by a different brand but looks similar. So we decided to see if the parts are compatible and lo and behind, they ARE! See video attached.

title: Good fun, but could be improved
text:
[[VIDEOID:3de7f6e3df19432668ace0c47a79c015]] This is a great game concept and is really fun to take some of the concepts that are popular in puzzle matching video games and bring it off screen.
It's an excellent proof of concept but I found it a little difficult to play with adult sized hands. See the video for more details.

title: Cute and keeps kids entertained
text: This is a cute toy whether you are fan of Chuggington or just like transforming driving toys. My 4 year old loves the Rescue Wilson engine with the included net trailer, its a really cool set and keeps him entertained for hours. The design of the toy is a little bit interesting- you can't fully open the trailer when it is attached, you have to detach it to get enough clearance to pop it open. And then, the net shooting part can be inserted and fired, which is fun. However it can't be stored inside the trailer, as when you fold it back up there is not enough room for the projectile inside the shell. It's kind of strange, you'd think they could design this to be a little bit longer so that it would fit and be able to open while attached to the character, however none of this seems to stop my kid from enjoying it.

title: Fun, but not high quality
text:
This is a cute and fun target practice game for kid and adults to play together. The goal post was easy enough to assemble, and it is fun when it works, but we noticed right away that the guns were not so intuitive to fire. For starters, you need to tilt it down to reload sometimes using gravity (to get the ball to the front) before the pump action can "fire". When it does fire, it gives a very satisfying POP sound, but it was a little frustrating for my younger kids to figure out how to keep it firing when the ball doesn't roll to the front.
The next problem is that after a couple of weeks of use, one of the guns has sort of broken off internally, so it now leaks air instead of firing when you pump it. It was a a lot of fun when it was new, and my kids still play with it despite only having one working gun, but it's a countdown until that one also breaks and we put this in the garbage. Until then, it's fun.

title: Simple and fun!
text:
This is a fun and unique game for all ages! The "Monster" requires some AAA batteries, so make sure you have those handy (it does not include them). The game play is beautifully simple: the electronic Monster has sensors that will make him jump forward or backward when you get close, the object is to save as many pieces as you can before he goes rampaging forward to gobble up whatever remains. Turns are taken and cards are drawn to indicate what each player has to do (move the toys, take toys, etc). The instructions are easy enough that anyone can play, and its fun for adults as well as kids.
It also comes with a puzzle- not part of the game, just a fun freebie to get kids excited about playing!

title: Classic, with the same cover art as 30+ years ago!
text:
I love this game. I played it as a kid growing up, even when I was younger than the age listed on the box. My dad, who loves logic and math, would play it and use it as teaching moments to understand deduction. I have to admit, I remember that box and the cover art from the 1980s being EXACTLY this. The bond-villain looking dude sitting in the chair with his smug body language, and the girl behind him made me feel like the game was aimed at someone more adult than I, yet the game itself was (and is) wonderfully simple and fun, with bright colored pegs that seem like something more kid-friendly than the box would otherwise imply.
This brings back so many memories, and now that I have kids of my own I intend to create new similar memories for the next generation.

title: Super toy, with some complex fun transformations!
text:
[[VIDEOID:66f00484756b6b668cabf4c35e8b6dab]] My youngest LOVES Super Wings. There was a time that it was the only thing he would watch. This is a super cool set with all the main characters, from the original three to the two newer ones (my son was ecstatic to see Golden Boy!).
They each have their own slightly different and unique way to transform from robot to vehicle, but I can't do it justice in text so I'll include a video.
Something to note since recording this video: My son came home today from school and didn't want to watch anything or use any screen time... he didn't want want a play date (all things he usually asks for ASAP when coming home). All he wanted was to play with Super Wings! Very pleased with this set.

title: Solid app but cube hardware can't keep up
text:
[[VIDEOID:df61075bc0172b4d34aec64cd5ddd45b]] The concept of smart cubes are really cool: They connect over Bluetooth low power protocol to an app so that your movements are digitized. This opens up possibilities like training exercises and real-time online competitions. The app is actually pretty excellent here, unlike another cube we tried, this one actually has competitors and it seems to work (however my son is suspicious that they might not be real players. They could be AI, because how many people could there really be using this app at the same time he is?).
However, the hardware seems buggy on this. Sometimes the cube will move and the app won't register that movement. Try it again later with the same move, and it does. In the video here, my son demonstrates that it completely loses calibration as he solves the cube. We tried the app on a few different devices in our home, with processors from Qualcomm Snapdragon and other's with Samsung's Exynos (flagship Galaxy S level hardware). It doesn't seem to be the phone/tablet that is the problem, but rather that the cube isn't always registering the movement to send to the app. This causes things to get out of alignment relatively quickly, especially when speed solving, and renders the entire experience frustrating.
This had so much potential, we're really disappointed.

title: Excellent magnetic levitation system!
text:
I actually had the opportunity to try this exact model from another brand, so I already knew what to do expect. The good news is that I love that cube and this is just as good- I would strongly recommend both of them.
Like the other cube I reviewed, this one has no springs at all, and uses opposite magnets which I think is incredible. A normal speed cube would have springs to hold it together and adjust the tension depending on your personal preference, but this one levitates with magnetism which gives you a unique friction-free experience. I strongly recommend this style for new cubers or experienced alike.

title: New incredible magnetic levitation system
text: I have several speed cubes, and this one really sticks out. This cube has no springs at all, and uses opposite magnets which I think is incredible. A normal speed cube would have springs to hold it together and adjust the tension depending on your personal preference. However when you have springs in a cube it can increase friction and can make an annoying squeak noise. This one fortunately doesn't do that because of the lack of springs, and the opposing magnets give you a unique friction-free floating experience. Whether you're into speed cubes or not, I recommend it, especially for the price.

title: Great for teaching patience
text:
My 4 year old was very excited about this "pet" for him. I love the idea of him taking care of something by checking in on it regularly, and having the patience to watch it change day by day. However, perhaps I overestimated his ability to wait- he was too excited and ended up ripping parts of the egg off after a day or two, which left parts still attached to the dragon. Thankfully there was a second egg so we could try again, but in the end he found the wait frustrating and lost interest because he wanted to take it out and play with it.
I love the concept, but make sure your kids are ready for it!

title: Surprisingly excellent!
text:
My son is into competitive cubing, so we decided to try out a skewb. We weren't sure what to expect since it does not describe any sort of features we're used to seeing advertised on speed cubes, such as the magnets or tensioning adjustment. All we knew was that it was somehow related to Gan's core which we have been impressed with. It turns out, this actually IS magnetic and has a adjustable tensioning system.
If you want to find the tension adjustment, you can pull off some of the corners and find an adjustment knob that can twist.
My son finds this puzzle extremely satisfying, and he would strongly recommend it for the price!

title: Strong Nerf-style blaster!
text:
This is a powerful Nerf gun clone with some cool spider-styling. The bullets are interchangeable with real Nerf ones, and the suction cup ends are actually really impressive! My kids managed to fire this at a spinning ceiling fan and they actually STUCK to the fan blades and stayed there for a solid few minutes!
The gun itself is great too, it shoots pretty far by the standards of other nerf-clones. However, it isn't the easiest to use. The bullets aren't as easy to load as other Nerf guns (the barrel does not come out to load, and you have to sort of carefully fish them in one at a time, rotating the barrel for each insertion), and my younger kids found the spring mechanism harder to pull back and load. This is understandable since the spring is so strong, but younger kids might find it too difficult to load.

title: Great value on 2 pack
text:
My kids love this set! Not only does it come with two different colored Nerf-compatible guns, it comes with 2 different set of nerf-style bullets, some that have the standard suction cup end (which can stick to windows, for example) and the other which is designed to be low impact (so shooting at each other is less likely to hurt).
The guns are clearly knock-offs and not the original Nerf quality, but for the price, you're getting 2x the guns, two different kinds of bullets and wrist bands to keep extra bullets on you. The guns are easy to load since the rotating barrel is open on the bottom, and the pull back action is easy enough for my kids to load and arm at any age. Would recommend!

title: Better than a tire swing
text: In our old house, my kids used to love our old tire swing, but the younger siblings have gotten bigger and simply won't fit on a car tire at the same time these days. These big disc-style swings are a GREAT alternative! You can lounge on it by yourself like a hammock, or have a bunch of kids laying on it together and they all enjoy it. The straps make it super easy to throw over a tree branch or deck beam, no permanent hardware installation necessary. My 13 year old son assembled it by himself following the instructions, it only took him about 15 minutes. This is a great addition to any yard!

title: Good for a non-magnetic, but why?
text: I've used many cubes, both recreationally and competitively. At this point, I'm so used to magnetic speed cubes, that the name Speed Cube to me implies a magnetic system. I've also used many Gan cubes and really enjoyed them, so I was a little thrown off by the lack of magnets on this one. To be fair, that's the selling point of this cube so I suppose there are people out there who might prefer a lighter one like this. Personally, I found it annoying since I'm so used to the magnets on other competitive cubes, so I'm not a fan and I'm not sure who the market for this is. However, for a non-magnetic cube, this is actually pretty good.  But then again, a non-magnetic cube can be had for less than this.

title: Its OK
text: After having several speed cubes, this one is just OK. It's not the fastest, and sometimes the magnetic mechanism doesn't respond the way I expect as it does with other cubes (the rows are supposed to stick together with certain motions, and with this cube they don't always). Oddly, when I took it out of the box it felt kind of oily, like they tried to overlubricate it at the factory. I've used more expensive models from this brand and I was impressed, so I know they can do it right. It seems weird how this one just barely missed the mark.

title: Its a very premium speed cube
text: I own several speed cubes from different brands, but of all of them I find myself using this one the most. The quality is really top notch, it isn't the cheapest but you really do get what you pay for. It comes with instructions to adjust magnetic strength, however I could not figure out how that works or if it really has that feature, which was disappointing. But otherwise, a really light and smooth motion cube, I highly recommend it. The only reason I give it 4 stars is because it is a little bit louder than other cubes, otherwise it really is one of the best I've ever tried!

title: Great for PJ Mask fans!
text: [[VIDEOID:2e430c9899ce6b8588082b1c90b4f3a3]] My 4 year old ADORES PJ Masks. How could I not get this for him? It's exactly what I expected and wanted, he LOVES it, and now spends time playing with his imagination instead of watching it for hours. Highly recommended!

title: Decent product, but door is a poor design choice
text:
Our old ball pit (an inflatable pool) popped, so I decided to try this out for our little guy. It seems to hold our 300+ balls nicely and takes up less space than the walls of an inflated kiddie pool indoors, which I very much like. However there's one design flaw I can't understand: the door on the back. Under the basketball hoop, there's a little door with some velcro squares and a couple of loops to hold it closed. I can't understand the purpose of this door. When my 4 year old jumps into the pit, the force causes the door to flex enough to start leaking balls out. If he roughs around too much, it starts leaking more, until we end up chasing dozens of balls around the playroom to clean it up.
I would easily give this 5 stars if not for that door. My daughter and wife are discussing sewing it closed with a needle and thread to solve this bizarre design flaw. It just shouldn't have that in my opinion.

title: Fun for the novelty of being a BIG game, but could be better
text:
We tried this recently on a rainy evening, and it was a fun family activity. However it feels like some things weren't fully thought through and could have been easily made better.
For example, the spinner needle feels like it stops exactly on the line more than half the time, causing much arguing and debate over which side it actually landed. If you have ever played the game Life or used a spinning prize wheel, you know there is a much better way to do this: Have plastic borders that catch on the needle so it stops in one space clearly (and makes a cool motor noise as it click-click-clicks quickly). Once you're making giant playing pieces and a large floor mat board, this would not have added a lot of cost and would have made the game infinitely more fun and smooth to play.
And speaking of giant playing pieces, once you assemble them, they don't fit back in the box unless you break them apart, something that probably won't last if you do it every time you put the game away. It could have come with a bag or something to store the game board and pieces in. As of now, I'm pretty sure the pieces and board are going to get separated from each other in our family room. It's a fun game, but unlike giant versions of Jenga, Connect Four or Chess, the novelty of giant Sorry wears off quickly and at some point my mother-in-law actually asked why we can't just play it on the table like a regular game. It's fun for the novelty, but the caveats and game mechanics make this not worth more than 3 stars in my opinion.

title: Decent magnetic cube, but cheaper versions out there
text:
This is not a bad magnetic speed cube, if it were competitively priced against others in the market I might even argue its a good deal. But, I'm sorry to say that it feels like a rebranding of one of the cheaper speed cubes I've owned. Those cheap cubes cost a fraction of the asking price here.
The magnets are kind of weak which makes it hard to control precisely, and you can't use corner-cut moves. It also doesn't have any useable way to adjust tension. All in all, this is a good cube if you can get it under $10. But for $20-30, you can definitely do better.

title: POW! WHAM! Its the BATMAN!
text:
I love the way DC has made Batman accessible on various levels over the years. The current DC Universe is full of dark and gritty characters, which is fun for adults but not so much for kids. Then there's the kid-friendly version, which this fits into. It's not as goofy as Lego batman (which, don't get me wrong, I LOVE too, but there's a time and place), but not as dark and scary as the adult Batman from the current DC movies. The vehicle is fun, my 4 year old loves it and it has ignited the same love of classic comic superheros that I had at his age.
Recommended for all, whether a fan of the Batman or not.

title: Fun for little athletes
text:
I really appreciate that this is adjustable, my 4 year old and his older siblings can use this and vary the height easily using the included parts. It's a lot of fun for them to practice their swing, as I'm writing this review my little one is looking over my shoulder and saying "oh, I love that one!"
The quality of material is decent, it should hopefully last for a couple of kids in our home, and the bright colored plastic makes it easy to find in the garage. A cute and fun gift for little athletes.

title: Can't get enough of these tracks!
text: I love that this can disassemble back into the box it comes in for storage, and that it actually USES THE BOX as part of the track! Of course, we know the real fun comes from pairing it up with other Hot Wheels track parts to build your epic track creation, but this set has a lot to keep you busy even on its own.
