I love that the launcher is completely mechanical, no batteries or electrical power needed, just simple machines like the classic Hot Wheels sets when I was a kid. My kids have had a blast with it so far, I can't recommend it enough!

title: Your kids love Paw Patrol? Get this and prepare for bumps on your baseboards!
text:
My kid absolutely ADORES Paw Patrol. I've gotten him some toys based on the show (and now movie!) and he always loves opening them up. The look in his eyes is priceless.
This toy is great, however I might argue that a 3 year old would have some trouble understanding the controls (it says ages 3 and up, my son is 4.5 and just barely understands how the steering works). It goes pretty fast and he giggles every time it crashes into the wall. Oh, on that note, be prepared for that. If you use this inside, your furniture and baseboards WILL get bumped. A lot. Pad them or let them play with it somewhere this is OK to do in your home. It honestly is big enough that it can probably be used outside, but I'd rather save it for a rainy day inside toy. It's totally worth having him crash into the walls and sofa, he's so happy doing it! Would recommend.

title: A fun loop track, but not 100% consistent
text:
[[VIDEOID:5e7f040ef313786f52e263eafa2f301a]] We love Hotwheels, and this set is no exception! There are many possibilities and ways to configure the parts, and of course it makes a great addition to using with pre-existing tracks and parts. However, following the directions for a recommended setup (2 loops and a jump into a holder), my kids actually had a hard time getting it to go consistently. It would often launch too fast and fall off the track before the first loop, or if we didn't hit it hard enough, it would fall down the first incline. We couldn't find that perfect balance of launching power. Then, other times it would just work consistently, like every time. I have no idea why.

The attached video is one of the first times we got it to work, and we can't explain why sometimes it worked every time and other times not at all. Overall a fun set and some great parts to add to your hot wheels track collection.

title: No included wand.
text:
Like another reviewer mentioned, mine also did not come with a wand. Interesting to note that the wording on the listing implies there is only ONE wand for all 6 bottles. It isn't 6 bottles with 6 wands like I expected it to be (most bubble solution bottles come with a plastic wand inside), it's supposed to be one apparently- but we didn't even get that.
The other reviewer claims to have reached out to get a wand from the manufacturer, but we decided to just use other wands we happened to have from other bubble products. The solution is good, so 3 stars for that for sure are warranted. But if a buyer is expecting a least one wand to be included, they are going to be frustrated having to contact the manufacturer to get one separately.

title: Its good for beginners, but not as exciting for advanced users
text:
This is a solid cube for learning on, and like the description states, it is very cool that it can be used without any additional screen or computer connected. There are little LED lights on the centers that recommend which way to rotate until eventually ending in a solved puzzle. However, the app DOES make it better and more useful/interesting. There are so many more things you can do, include watching the cube in real time.
Here's what we found, however: My son has been to cubing competitions, he knows how to solve it already, he was hoping to learn some new techniques and participate in challenges, which is something he has heard of smart cubes doing. This one seems like a newer product that is still evolving- at the time we tried it, there were no challenges available for him. He reached out to tech support and was told that challenges are not available now, but rather is a feature they hope to make available soon. The built in solves were kind of boring to him as well- it mostly just remembered the moves he made and suggested doing it in reverse. That's not very exciting or "smart".
He also had some trouble at one point in which the cube stopped responding to his phone and needed to reach out to tech support again to get it working. All in all, this is very cool as a concept and has a lot of potential, but I can't really give it 5 stars. I'd say 4 at best and maybe 5 in the future if they manage to get this up and going properly.

title: My son's favorite 5x5
text:
My son has been competitive cubing, and we've liked other cubes from this brand before. Their 7x7 was pretty good, the 6x6 not so much, but the 5x5 (this one) is our favorite one so far. Not just our favorite from this brand, but he has used other 5x5 cubes and finds this one to be his favorite. This one seems to have a smooth feel and an impressive anti pop mechanism.
If you want a budget 5x5 puzzle, this is the one to get!

title: Its OK, but there are better for the price
text:
After trying a 7x7 from this brand, I had high hopes for their 6x6. Honestly, maybe I just got a bad copy because their 7x7 was a lot smoother out of the box than this one was, and that should have been a more complicated mechanism.
This was kind of rough and slow out of the box, I'd hardly call it a "speed" cube, and at one point it got halted so badly a piece popped over when my son tried to move it. I think we can get it back on, but so far we have not been able to. I feel like for the price there are better 6x6 puzzle cubes.

title: A really fun and futuristic variation of the classic!
text:
If you were to imagine how they might play Uno in some science fiction future, it would probably go something like this. The rules and concept are largely the same as the classic, but with some fun variation that makes it more interesting: There is now a computerized set of 3 active play piles which add some fun surprises and cool sci-fi sound effects to the game. This sounds more complicated, but honestly after the first couple of rounds it will totally make sense- and be a heck of a lot of fun for family game night!
Instead of a single active playing pile, the lights tell the player which piles he can choose to play (one or two or all three), and after each turn they press down on the pile to tell the computer to move on to the next player. However when a pile is picked too often, an internal counter can tell it to "overload" and penalize the player with drawing more cards (how close you are to overload is shown with green/yellow/red lights). There are some new cards to mix it up a bit two, including one which just requires players go around pressing until one overloads in a sort of Russian-roulette style mini-game inside the game. One card lets you "reload" and start the overload counter over on a particular pile (which makes a satisfying charge up sound effect). Overall it adds some drama and fun to an already classic and fun card game.

HOWEVER- this new game is not without some caveats. The biggest one? Making a mistake on your turn and mixing up the gameplay can't be undone. To explain:
Let's say someone accidentally presses a pile while reaching for the one they intend to use... especially if they cause that pile to "overload", it can really mix up the counter for everyone else playing. We had a couple of moments in which someone accidentally triggered the pile button twice on their turn instead of once, and then then the next player couldn't play the card they wanted to because the pile was no longer active that should have been.
Essentially, the computer needs some sort of "UNDO" button or something to go back one step in case something goes wrong. Ideally it shouldn't happen, but when playing with 4 kids aged 8-13, it happened at least 3 or 4 times out of two full games played that I witnessed. If they added an undo button I'd give the game 5 stars, its really fun! I still recommend it, but please be careful not to mess up the game during play!

title: Good for a 7x7
text:
The bigger these cube puzzles get, the more complicated and intricate the parts need to be. The good news about this one is that I've tried a bunch of cubes from the same brand in smaller sizes, and the movement is almost identical to their smaller (and simpler) counterparts.
The flip side is that their cubes aren't necessarily the fastest and smoothest out there compared to popular speed cubes. It'll work for learning and practice and just having fun with a puzzle, but they aren't necessarily as smooth as competition grade movement.
Adding some cube lubricant to it helps a little if you want to speed it up, but it's about on par with other budget cubes. I like it as do my kids who are competitive cubers, and for the money it is a decent value.

title: Pretty and just the right amount of difficulty
text:
This is one of those puzzles that are rewarding to do.
The colors are vivid and pretty, it makes you want to frame it on the wall when complete. There's just enough variation to make it interesting without being too repetitive to be frustrating when assembling. In other words, it's difficult enough to feel accomplished without being too difficult that you want to quit. Puzzles like these are relaxing and fun, I recommend it for those who appreciate them!

title: Right out of the show!
text:
[[VIDEOID:43662f7537367d0844b76b522934c0c7]] What a fun toy for Paw Patrol fans!
I'm including a video because describing it won't do it justice. It's fun, but closing the doors was a little harder than we expected for a youngster. My kids adore it however!
Note: This only comes with one character and solo vehicle inside. Action figures for the pups and other vehicles are sold separately.

title: My son LOVES this!
text:
I've got a 4 year old who's into excavators and diggers and trucks... all the stereotypical things a boy his age would be into. I can't even describe the glee on his face when he opened this up! He was so excited, I didn't even get a chance to help him build it, his older sister helped him assemble it by themselves (mom helped with the finishing touches). So, I can vouch that assembly was easy enough that I didn't even need to get involved, and mom just needed to snap some final parts on. He rode around the house picking up small dolls and things with his digger arm, and then took it outside and treated it like one of the family vehicles. In fact, right now it is parked next to our cars on the driveway.
What a cute riding toy for an imaginative kid. Highly recommended!

title: Good balls but small quantity
text: These are a good size and good quality, however for the price you don't really get all that many. They are a good addition to our current ball pit since a good number of balls have been crushed over time, so it was cool to just drop these in to add to it. But for the money you'll get better cost per ball if you get a larger quantity. Definitely not enough to start a pit on its own.

title: Good cheap sticker-less cube
text:
My kids are very competitive about solving these speed cubes, so we've had plenty of them in various shapes and sizes around here. This one is a pretty decent 3x3. It's stickerless, which means the plastic is painted the different colors instead of being colored stickers that can fade or be ripped off. It has smooth hinges and the magnetic bits means it will snap into position.
Basically, these aren't the Rubik's from 30 years ago that I was playing with, these are much better. A good value.

title: Fun puzzle cube variant
text:
My kids have mastered the 3x3, 4x4, 5x5, the pyramid and other puzzles. A 1x3 seems easy in comparison, but it's a different sort of challenge due to the way it works, and they enjoy it. Seems similar in build quality to other speedcubes on Amazon that we've tried, so I wouldn't be surprised if they are all coming from the same facility overseas.
If you've into puzzle cubes, complete your set with this one!

title: More of a fidget toy than "speed cube" but fun
text:
My 13 year old son loves puzzle cubes and fidget spinners, so he was very excited for this.
I have to say, as a puzzle, it's really more of a token thing than an ACTUAL puzzle toy. Don't get this just for the speed cube part. But as a spinner / fidget toy, it's fun, and the puzzle element makes it more interesting to play with. For what it is, it's a great toy or gift.

title: Imaginative and fun!
text: My 4 year old loves this, and in many ways this is levels beyond hot wheels and similar track sets. The track parts are pliable so that you can create curves and loops ramps using the included accessories, and in addition to the battery operated cars, there are plenty of terrain details to dress up and create an entire setting with. It promotes imagination and creativity by asking your child to plan ahead how a series of events will unfold (electric car looping around, will it collide with itself, etc), and then watching it play out. Really cute, well made, and overall excellent toy. I'm a fan!

title: Excellent cards
text: My son is very into card decks, he's been using them for card tricks for years now. These remind us a lot of the Joker & Thief brand cards, higher end than your average deck and really feels good to hold. The print is cool, he really likes them. Definitely an upgrade from standard cards if you want a cool deck.

title: Fantastic and LARGE!
text: What a great way to add some festivity (and visibility?) to your next party! I picked this up as a surprise for my wife's birthday, and I have to admit it's something to behold to have a giant sign this big! It practically takes over our deck, or could have been mounted inside where it would surely take over our living room (might try that one next time). It's festive and fun, the build quality is good, I intend to wrap this back up and reuse it again!

title: Really fun LEGO compatible plastic brick set!
text: My kids LOVE lego sets, and this plastic brick clone caught my eye as a cost-effective alternative. Yes, they are compatible with standard Lego bricks. Yes, they have some perks and parts you won't find in a standard Lego set, which is what makes it even more interesting and fun! Legos have always been the gold standard and cost what they do for a reason, but I have to say while you can tell these aren't standard Lego brand when you compare them side by side, its a really great set for the money. I'd recommend it!

title: So cute and fluffy! and HUGE
text:
I got this as part of an anniversary reveal with some other gifts for my wife waiting for her. It is adorable and exactly what I wanted from the listing! It comes vacuum packed into a small package which expands upon cutting the package open, and also comes with a giant red and clear cellophane bag to put it in as a gift!
The only thing I didn't really love is the checkered kerchief. I wanted to replace it with a red one to go with the theme of the anniversary gifts and it was harder than I wanted it to be to remove it (I just put a different kerchief over it). Otherwise, it is a really cute and fluffy bear!

title: Fun for truck fans
text:
My son loves monster trucks and hotwheels, so I figured this was a great match! It's a fun set for sure, but I guess I expected it to be a little bit more than it is.
It's got a mechanical part to hit to propel the car up a ramp, and the idea is supposed to be to hit it hard enough that it will smash the cars on a pedestal (empty shell plastic vehicles for effect are included). It's not all that easy for my 4 year old to hit, so I thought it would be disappointing for him. However, he just loves the hotwheels monster truck, so I guess it's a win anyway?
Reading some of the other reviews here, I think the consensus is that kids enjoy this set even if the adults were hoping it was more. And that's what really matters. But if you wanted something more innovative from hotwheels, this isn't it.

title: Not a great "speed" cube
text:
Maybe we're just spoiled by some of the excellent speed cubes we've tried recently, but this one really didn't impress. The movements aren't as smooth as our 3x3 speed cubes, and the hinges seemed to make a bit of noise like they weren't lubricated well. We tried to rectify that (as we have done with others) and the corner popped off and won't go back on.
Honestly, we could have used it as-is and it would have been a workable puzzle toy, but it was not a quality experience.

title: Super cool! But delicate
text:
[[VIDEOID:22856e2123af58886b875aa415fb3b17]] This thing is capable of making impossibly large and fun bubbles. My kids were having a blast with it today- if you hold still it will blow a large bubble, or if you pull backwards it will make many smaller ones. It takes a little bit of skill, unlike traditional bubble guns that just shoot dozens of bubbles in any direction by pulling the trigger. My four year old, for example, had some trouble getting it to work so we had to help him. We also noticed that the fan blades are kind of delicate and it started colliding with the frame after only using it for 10 minutes. I was able to bend them back to continue using it, but it seems a little weird that I had to keep doing that on a brand new product.
All in all, I still think it is worth 4 stars on account of just being really cool that you can create these giant awesome looking bubbles. But you have to be careful with it.

title: Excellent, Fast, and SMOOOOTH
text:
[[VIDEOID:aa2ebfd007ef4147a97d8623e09d69f3]] We're super into these Rubik's style puzzles in our family, and my oldest son has been through quite a few "speed cubes" before. But this is definitely the smoothest one to date. The moving parts are like butter, and the magnetic stops make everything feel like perfectly precise movements. See attached video of the last few steps of him solving it. I've never seen him do it this quickly and smoothly before! It's very satisfying.
I particularly like that there's even a way to adjust the tension to make it harder/easier to move to your linking (close up picture of adjustment screw under center piece included as well).
All in all, I'm impressed with this and would recommend it as a noticeable cut above your average toy cube.

title: Decent quality, a little pricey
text: These are another generic magnetic tile system based on the hugely popular magna-tiles sets. The quality is pretty good, these are fun to play with and encourage creative building, and seem plenty durable for kids to play with. Discovery Toys is a good brand, too, but the original Magna-Tiles are around the same price if not not a bit cheaper in some places. There's plenty of generic magnetic tile systems which offer nearly double the tiles for less money than this, so I have a hard time recommending it for the price, unless you really just prefer the Discovery Toys brand name.

title: Fun for older kids to play with younger ones
text: I don't know why this product got such negative reviews from others. I got it and we've been pretty happy with it. My older kids (8 and 11) use the parts when playing with our youngest (4 years) to build a little marble track out of Lego style bricks. The younger kid really likes it, and it promotes some out-of-the-box thinking compared to traditional brick building. The nice thing is that it appears to be compatible with Lego brand so you can mix and match stuff in all kinds of fun combos. I mean, I guess the actual instructions to build the track are kind of boring, and that one course would get old pretty fast. But like all brick building sets, who builds only the thing on the box? They seem to have fun playing with this one.

title: Perfect, especially for multiple kids!
text:
I was a little nervous because of the negative reviews, but this seems to actually be exactly what I expected- a 3 pack of the original brand name Slinky in plastic! My kids love this and I get to reintroduce them to the silly fun we all had when we were kids. Some people say the metal is the only "original", but I remember plastic was an option when I was a kid too, and unlike the metal, the plastic is relatively easy to fix if it gets a minor tangle (just follow the contours and trace it with your finger until it snaps back into place- as opposed to the metal which could bend and never really bend back into place). The only catch is that the plastic is also easily broken if you have to bend it too far to fix. But that's true of all slinkys, so as usual- be careful not to get it tangled!
I love that this 3 pack comes in multiple colors. I have multiple kids so they can each pick one and not fight about it. And simultaneous slinky races is totally a thing we all need in our lives. I love it!

title: Really cool! But the novelty wears off
text: This is a pretty cool toy! It plays a handful or pre-recorded songs while it dances on spider legs and lights up. At first it's really cute, and my 4 year old really loved it, but the novelty quickly wore off as it appears that's ALL it does. There isn't a lot of imaginative play, and if you don't like the songs (they're kind of annoying honestly), too bad. I wish it had an option to dance to music it hears, I've seen toys that do that with a little mic to hear the beat of music you play at it. This doesn't. It just moves in pre-recorded motions. It doesn't interact with you at all, it doesn't do anything else really. It's one of those toys that is fun and exciting for the first couple of days, then you're over it. There's nothing wrong with that as a fun novelty gift, just don't expect more.

title: Perfect for filling DIY ball pits!
text:
This is a great deal on a large quantity of plastic balls. The balls are cool colors (mint and light pinks and yellows), and it comes in a handy zipper storage cube. I love this because it actually got to serve as an excellent surprise for my wife. We always joked that when we own our own house, there would be a "ballroom" which would actually be a room full of balls. Well, now we own a home and I can't actually FILL a room with balls, but I can use this to fill a closet with them. I left a note for her to check for a surprise, and she opened the door to a full comedic effect of these balls pouring out, with a note saying "to our new ballroom". It was amazing and perfect, and reminded her that I never forgot those conversations. It also gave me new appreciation for how prank shows handle this sort of setup- it was actually really hard to fill the closet without them falling out as I did! (hint: the solution involved using cardboard as a barrier and then pulling it out carefully as I closed the door)
After that, we filled the closet back up and repeated the prank for my kids, who immediately started swimming and laughing in them. All in all, I'm very appreciative of this set being made available and highly recommend it!

title: Rocket car!
text:
My youngest child is head over heels with this car. The "rocket" part in the back is a stroke of genius! It shoots out a water mist with a colored light that makes it feel like it is shooting out a thruster akin to the Batmobile! I was a little bit afraid at first that it would get our hardwood floors wet, but it seems to just be a vapor like a humidifier that evaporates completely into the air.
The remote controls are easy to operate and the car is pretty fast too! The only issue is that the motor seems to have burnt out by the second day running it around the house. The controls all work, but forward/reverse is dead. We got it replaced and the second one seems better now, but I will update this review if it burns out again. It is possible we just had a dud the first time.

title: High quality model!
text: I found this to be surprisingly high quality for a toy. The vehicle can make a variety of sounds by pressing down on the rear suspension, and it is able to drive on its own two wheels without falling over. You can even adjust the steering via the handle bars in order to choose if it will drive straight or in a curve. The detail on it is impressive! I love motorcycles and my youngest son has started a fascination with them as well. This is a great little bonding toy for the two of us to play with!

title: QUALITY cards
text: We own a few Joker and the Thief playing card decks, and they have always been top notch quality. This may be the classiest one I've tried to date, and definitely does not disappoint! The cards are made with such precision, you can feel it in your hands. The printing and graphics on this deck are excellent as expected, however this one has a more classical style than the others we own and it just overall exudes a high end look and feel. They aren't cheap for a reason- if you like quality playing cards, you've found them. My son has been practicing amateur card tricks (both physical and illusion) and the Joker and the Thief are clearly his go-to for showcasing his talents.

title: So much fun!
text: [[VIDEOID:28aff20167d7e3d5b28e725ad1b8f30f]] This is a great game! I have fond memories of knock hockey when I was a kid, but this is NEXT LEVEL! The idea is to use the rubber band like a slingshot and try to be the first to flick all your pucks to the other side. I thought it might be too difficult from the pictures, but in real life this is actually easy and fun! Think of it like Angry Birds meets Knock Hockey. I love this!

title: Fun while it lasts
text: My youngest loves toy cars and police vehicles, so I figured he'd appreciate this set as a new distraction. The truth is, the set feels very cheaply made and it took his older siblings quite some time to figure out how to get it together properly. Even then, it didn't seem to stay "together" for very long. But that's honestly ok, for the price you get a lot of parts and things to play with that will keep your kid occupied and interested until it wears off for the next thing. This isn't the sort of toy you should invest it for long term use, it won't last. But if your kid breaks things anyway and just wants something new, you could do a lot worse than this for the money.

title: Fun and simple game!
text:
This is a great family friendly game that people of all ages can play. The concept is simple in that you need to just try to anticipate what others will play, sort of like rock-paper-scissors. But this game can have multiple players at a time and last until someone either collects enough winning cards (pieces of garbage) or is the last player standing.
The caveats are that you have the ability to "play it safe", which can avoid getting out if someone accuses you of trying to steal on your turn. This can lead to many rounds where nothing happens as someone needs to steal or accuse of stealing for the game to progress. It is also possible to start feeling repetitive after some time as the gameplay does not allow for much variation to keep it interesting. For what it is, it is a fun quick game that doesn't require a lot of setup or learning. But don't expect it to last a long time before people want to do something else instead.

title: What a blast! Better than powerwheels!
text:
Note: We had a minor issue unpacking the unit because some of the parts are stored in the cab part of the vehicle and need to be gently removed. My kids, excited to build this, yanked out the parts with too much force and actually broke the accelerator pedal right off!
Some Gaff Tape and a heat gun later, I was able to make it manageable to use again, but please be careful unpacking the parts from the box!
That being said, this is a fun little car! My kids love it ranging from age 10 to 3, and I love that it has a little safety governor that can be removed with a screw driver for high speed, or just leave it on the default low for younger drivers. The vehicle has its own little radio that even includes an aux cable to wire up your favorite music player and cruise around the block to your own tunes! It's got working headlights too, which are mostly for show but still super cute and adds fun for the kids. We had an old power wheels vehicle years ago, but this seems to have more features. Very impressed with it, and with a name like Radio Flyer behind it, I won't be surprised if this lasts through quite a bit of roughhousing.

title: Fun kid projects!
text: This is a very cute set that my 10 year old daughter loves! She is into projects and crafts so this is perfect for her, however she found the instructions were a little bit complicated to follow. It does not seem to have thwarted her enthusiasm however, and she still loves making bracelets with it.

title: Excellent classic fun!
text:
We had an old Mancala board that we lost in a move, so this was exciting for my family to get! The board is well made and hinged to fold up for storage. It also comes with plenty of extra "seeds" marbles, so losing one or two over time won't stop you from playing! (our old one had a few, um, "other" items as seeds over the years)
I taught our kids how to play over the weekend, and it's been pretty much non stop asking who is playing next for the last 36 hours!
A great classic game that should be a staple of any household.

title: Brings me back!
text:
I remember playing with these as a kid, hearing my dad explain how the light spectrum works and being fascinated by it! Now that I have kids of my own, I want to give them similar experiences. Obviously I jumped at the opportunity to try this out, and it is just as interesting as I remember it. I got a lot of "oohs" and "whoas" from the kids when I showed them how it works by a window, and now they show it to their friends when they come over.
Proud dad moment. I actually really like how well this is packaged, it comes in a long sized jewelry-style box to protect and store it easily. Thank you Amazon, for reminding me to share these moments with my kids.

title: Make clean up time part of the fun!
text: My son is over the moon with this toy! I mean, come on- to a 3 year old boy, sharks, cars, and sharks that EAT cars?! I don't know what discussion was going on over at Hot Wheels HQ when this product was pitched, but whatever it is, THANK YOU FOR IT! What a bizarre but delightful toy! The shark munches its jaws up and down as you push the toy along, and any hot wheels (and other compatible sized) cars in its way will get sucked up inside! What's great about this aside from the fun playing it, is that my kid is actually helping CLEAN UP by playing. Now when we say time to clean up, he's excited to use the car eating shark! I wish it fit more cars at a time, but then the toy would understandably be much larger.

title: Pull-back hotwheels-compatible cars!
text:
My kids love Hot Wheels, but this DRIVEN branded alternative seems like a more budget friendly alternative with a killer feature: pull back motors! While Hot Wheels relies on either gravity or motorized / elastic band powered locomotion on the track, these cars can be self-powered, which opens up all kinds of new track and stunt possibilities!
Are the cars as good as Hot Wheels? No, you won't get the detail and metal scale body vehicles that Hot Wheels offers. These are plastic mostly, however they seem pretty durable, and they will fit on most hot wheels track. They do sell DRIVEN branded stunt tracks as well, and I have had the opportunity to try that out as well (spoiler: It was fun! And also compatible with Hot Wheels track parts). I think these are an excellent value.

title: Excellent Hot Wheels alternative (and compatible!)
text:
My kids love car sets like Hot Wheels, however even basic jump or loop parts can get pretty pricey. I was not familiar with this brand before, but I have to admit I'm impressed. It is not only similar quality and feel to Hot Wheels, the parts are mostly interchangeable. It seems that all the DRIVEN car sets I'm seeing have pull-back action cars, which means instead of just gravity or relying on tricks of the track to get propulsion (motorized bumpers, rubber band powered kickers, etc) which Hot Wheels usually uses, this car can actually propel itself through stunts. That opens up some pretty interesting track ideas and possibilities, especially when combined with traditional Hot Wheels track parts.
I think considering the retail value of this, it is an excellent deal and would recommend it.

title: Great gift for kids who like to create art
text: My 7 year old daughter fell in love with this product right away. It reminds me of the black crayon art things we used to make in school as a kid, only a much neater version. She loves making patterns out of shapes and proudly showing everyone in the family before going and taping it to her wall. The kit comes with stencils for shapes to scratch out as well as stickers, but my daughter wasn't as interested in the stickers part. I'll admit, it's nice they included it but the stickers don't really go. It also has a brush to help clean up the debris from the scratched off bits. A very cute kit that will be appreciated by any artistic kid!

title: SUPER fun and simple!
text:
This is the sort of game you can quickly just pick up and play for a minute or two and then put away. The concept is simply whoever can hit the buttons faster wins. In our family, I've found it has the impromptu challenge appeal of arm wrestling ("whoever can beat me a quick game gets to win the last slice of dessert!") to the decision making appeal of rock-paper-scissors ("who's turn is it to do dishes tonight? PLAY YOU FOR IT!").
That being said, the game is over very quickly and does get repetitive pretty fast. But it's the sort of game that is fun to have around the house. Anyone at any age can play it, we really like it!

title: SO MUCH FUN!
text:
[[VIDEOID:a44e8134f18099fbd4fabe70bbedcd25]] I can't remember any other toy that had all my kids this interested and laughing together as much as this one. This car has multiple modes which are fun and interesting, but the chase one had them (especially my 3-year-old) in absolute stitches trying to catch. The car has sensors that make it similar to a fly... as soon as you get too close, it jumps away, making it difficult to catch for tiny hands. The amount of laughing that following this is worth every penny! The other modes, such as the line track tracing, are interesting and fun for kids to play with as well, but there's 2 major caveats I have with this toy:
1) THE MUSIC IS REPETITIVE AND TERRIBLE. It plays music while on. Over and over and over. The follow trace mode sounds like some sort of Spanish song, which isn't bad at all... the first 50 times you hear it. After that, you want to scream to shut it off. My kids love this thing but they can't use it without annoying my wife. Yes, there's a button on the remote control to toggle music, but you also don't need the remote control to use it so my kids would play with it by itself ("where's the remote?!" "we don't need it!") for hours and my wife had no way to turn off the looping music.
2) The car itself does not use standard batteries, rather it has a tiny little circular charging port. It comes with a little wire to charge it with, but much like the remote, it is often missing and very easy to misplace. In fact, as of this writing we haven't been able to find the charging cable for a few days. I'm sure it'll turn up eventually, but it begs the question: Couldn't they have made this a standard charging port like a micro-USB or something? The proprietary charging cable on an obscure device like this is a great disservice to an otherwise super fun product! Standards are good for things like this, people!

That being said, this product is enough fun that I REALLY want to give it 5 stars. But the caveats need to at least take one away. It's almost perfect!

title: Fun, but not what we expected.
text:
[[VIDEOID:6ec6d97ac2839d9ee3f7fabd48d195e4]] The product listing here makes it seems like something more than it really is. I was expecting a moving target toy that opens its mouth on a motorized interval and we have to aim and time it correctly to hit the bullseye. Sort of like those mini-golf challenges they have out there. Turns out, the mouth is just a hinge you move by hand and then leave set up. It also doesn't come with any instructions, and speaks only in what appears to be Chinese. See video for further explanation.
Not mentioned in the video: Sometimes the shooter does not fire if the balls have rolled to the back of the blaster. You may need to roll them to the front and try again. Overall, it is NOT the experience I was expecting. If you understand that it is not motorized and apparently not made for an English audience, and that the shooters are not high quality, it's actually fun. But I felt disappointed by the description versus actual product received.

title: Great for kids who enjoy vehicle toys!
text:
I have an almost-4-year-old who loves vehicle toys, and this set is right up his alley! The bigger vehicle can enclose one of the 2 included mini-bikes, and then launch it with a button on the top, or just pull-back on the larger one and the entire thing propels itself forward. Encourages a lot of imagination play, and the construction seems higher quality than I expected for the price. The parts that snap together make a satisfying "click", and the launching mechanism is equally satisfying to use. The larger vehicle has optional batteries to make noises, but you can leave it out and the toy is just as much fun. I opted to leave it out and not tell him about this option so that it doesn't just make noise in the background all day- I prefer that he use his imagination for things like that.
I'd say its a good value and makes a cute gift!

title: My kids love this!
text: This adds so much fun to a backyard with minimal effort to set up! We hung it by a branch so the kids can use the trunk of the tree to walk up, and they LOVE challenging themselves to see which color they can make it to. The older siblings can also use it for traditional rope climbs, and the coloring gives a fun whimsical vibe to the yard. Was super easy to install, I highly recommend it!

title: Great for creating games or tricks!
text: My son has been working on his amateur magician act, and wanted to create some card tricks of his own. This deck is great as it lets him create his own "trick" cards with whatever he wants on them (or nothing at all, if the trick calls for disappearing cards). They feel and shuffle like regular playing cards, they are good quality for a niche product. He's been really enjoying them so far, I recommend it for anyone looking to do the same.

title: Still an excellent drone, even with the sequel available
text:
I've been flying a Phantom 3 for years to get dramatic birds-eye shots in corporate video, but I needed to replace it after a fatal crash on a job recently. I was considering one of the new Mavic Pros, but I couldn't pass up on a deal for this kit. Yes, the Mini 2 just came out and adds a bunch of requested features, most notably 4k recording. However, the 2.7k of this camera is more than adequate for my work, and still gives you the ability to punch in a bit if you want to reframe on a 1080 timeline.
The most important part of this fly more pack is the spare batteries- Those are expensive, and while the prop cage and other extras are nice, the batteries are worth far more than the difference in price. I got this kit on sale for about the same price as the regular Mini, and it was a no brainer. It does everything my Phantom did, but is better at it. Yes, the mini 2 is out now and improves some of the features, but in 2020 the mini original is still relevant and an excellent value if you can get one on sale.
One caveat:
My phone (an LG G7) has an unreliable USB port. It's been broken for nearly a year. I charge with a wireless Qi charger so it has never been important for me to replace my phone. For the Phantom, you connect via a Wifi SSID with your device. With this, however, I need to use a USB connector to the phone. That's annoying, I can't actually use my phone with it so I had to dig up my old phone out of retirement and make that the official drone handset. I can't fault the Mavic Mini for this, really I should get a working phone. But I thought it was interesting that this was never an issue with my Phantom, its only an issue now.
I still highly recommend this for advanced and beginner users.

title: Simple and fun!
text:
This is a great family game for all ages, a simple concept that is still challenging enough to be fun. The concept is sort of Jenga-like, in that you have to carefully remove pieces of the "tower", however in this case the tower is a tree, you have to use a toy ax instead of your fingers to tap at it, and you only want the bark on the outside- if you knock out the trunk, you lose points!
The official rules call for only 2 hits, however we found that too difficult to play so we decided to double it to 4 taps per turn and the game has improved in our household. Definitely a little different and a lot of fun!

title: Excellent party balloons!
text: We tried this out for a backyard party that we wanted to dress up a bit more. The color and confetti clearly visible inside actually a touch of class and sophistication to the event. Even the ones that popped accidentally and sent a shower of confetti around us was awesome. Really enjoyed this!

title: Great toy
text: My youngest boy loves this train set! He was so excited to open it and play, it was pretty easy to get it up and going, but at first there's a lot that isn't self explanatory. I think my son wanted to control the train via the buttons on the side, however those only seem to make a difference when the train passed that part of the track, which was hard for him to understand. The sound effects are super cute and overall I'd say the build quality is quite good! I just wish the control made more sense to the children in the age group this is designed for.

title: Great party decoration
text: We had a party in a tent that we wanted to add some extra class to, so we tried this balloon set. The sticky tape held them in patterns around the tent poles which was really great, and really added to the overall aesthetic. Some of the balloons actually came defective (hole / already popped), so removing one star for quality control. However there were still plenty of balloons left over afterwards, so it wasn't a problem in our case.

title: Really Unique and Fun!
text:
This is a really cool and interesting game! I wasn't sure what to expect based on the box and description, but unlike other contraption based games I've played (like the classic "mouse trap" from my youth), this is more of a cooperative play game.
There are 4 strings that move a (clearly mission-impossible inspired) suspended character around the playing board, and it takes careful pulling and releasing each of them as a group effort to navigate properly, sort of like a marionette puppet meets a corporate team building activity. There are some things to do like remove security cameras and traps but the truth is, the real fun doesn't start until you open up the jewel cage.
Once the cage is open, there's a countdown (you can hear the spring noise whirring as soon as it opens) and the police car starts to slowly circle the board. If you make it to the getaway car with the jewel before the car makes it to block your path, you win! If, however, you take too long, the police car will spring into place and block your path. Hilarity ensues as players start to panic and lose their cool, and in the end, whether you make it or not, it felt exciting.
Things I like about the game:
- It is cooperative, not individual. So you don't "beat" another player, you work as a team to complete the task in time.
- The mechanical game board is unique and really fun to learn
- It does NOT require batteries! The board uses spring loaded timers where necessary, no electricity. This is cool in a decidedly analog way.
- People can walk over and see how it is played and join with very little instruction

Things I did not, however, like:
- The truth is, when playing with my kids, we sort of skipped the first part of the game and just jumped to the jewel part. The designers of this game tried to make it longer by adding disarming traps and pulling security cameras in particular order based on cards, but it felt tedious after a few rounds. Really the fun part is the end. The whirring police car gives a sense of danger and urgency that makes it fun.
- That little spy is suspended by strings that get tangled so quickly and easily. It feels like I sneeze and they are tangled. Out of the box, I had to spend time untwisting it before we played for the first time, so be careful.

That being said, the game is TON of fun for different ages and we actually had some guests come over who looked at it and wanted to play too (adults AND kids). They all asked where to to get it, so it might become a regular thing found in our neighborhood. I'd say it deserves 5 stars, it's been a while since a game sparked this much interest that wasn't on a screen.

title: A really interesting puzzle fidget toy
text: This is one of those toys that is great to have around, pick up and start fiddling with. It is very unique and interesting, my kids really got a kick out of it. It is well made and a really cool design, I recommend it very highly if you like fidgety toys.

title: My kid loves this!
text: My 3.5 year son is big into robots, and I KNEW he'd love this. When he opened the box, the look in his eyes was priceless! I expected it to be above his level, which it is, but that he'd have fun mashing buttons and making it do stuff. Turns out, he's terrified of it when it is on! He prefers the unit powered off and would rather play with his imagination. Super cute, I love it. His older brother started playing with the remote and making it do stuff when the younger one isn't around, it's a pretty impressive little toy to be honest.

title: Decent
text: These are an OK value. I like the quantity that comes in the set, but the quality of them are just alright. Like most inexpensive water balloons, inflate them too long and they will blow. They are the smaller kind, so know that you can't make these very large without them bursting on you. If you can't find an inexpensive set in a local discount store, this is a good alternative, but I often find things like this cheap locally.

title: A fun toy that brings me back
text:
I remember learning about centripetal force as a kid with my own gyroscope my dad gave me, so I was happy to get one of these to share with my kids and to relive some of my experiences.
It's cool to see the light bulb in their eyes as they hold it spinning and I tell them to try to rotate their arms. Suddenly it makes sense why bikes are easier to ride while moving, and it opens up all kinds of interest in rotation physics. The one I used to have as a kid came with a string you could balance it on and a notch in one end, and as long as it was spinning and you placed the notch over the string, it would balance like a tight rope walker. This one doesn't do that. It came with a string so I thought it would, but it turns out that's just extra string for the pull cord. Which, it happens, I was thankful for since after about 48 hours of owning it, my kids managed to get the string wound up into the axle where it pinched and got caught. Trying to remove it ripped the string off leaving some inside. I had to use a pocket knife and fine tweezers to get it out enough to spin again, so hurray for extra string?
Anyway, it does spin quite well so I'll give it that. I feel like the ergonomics of winding it could be better (there's no starting hole), and I wish it weren't so easy for string to get caught inside, but I have to give it credit: it is a fun toy. My kids sort of pointed out that it's similar to a fidget spinner, and that blew my mind. I had never made the connection that the gyroscope I loved so much as a kid was actually the OG fidget spinner. The literature inside the box even has a line that says "waste your time efficiently, which I found amusing. The box has some fun wording as well (designed in 2020 when there was "nothing else to do, anyway"!), however you can clearly see this was made in China and not proofread very well.
In a nutshell, it isn't perfect, but it is very good for what it is. A solid 4 star rating.

title: This is the way?
text: What a cute game! It reminds me of games that involved flicking plastic frogs into a target as a kid, only this one features "The Child" from the Mandalorian Star Wars TV series (aka Baby Yoda in internet speak) as the target. My kids loves the series with me so far and this was a fun and exciting gift for us to play together. Unlike the plastic flicking frogs of my youth, however, these are squishy and require launchers, which I admit is much cooler. If you're wondering why this game is the way it is, it's because the child eats frogs as a recurring comedic theme in the show.  A lot of fun for fans and anyone who enjoys target-hitting table games.

title: Simple and fun!
text:
These are a great value for the price!
My kids go through kites very quickly, so having a two-pack is actually a very welcome feature here! These were very easy to assemble, and work exactly as expected. They aren't the most durable kites, but for the price they are more than satisfactory. A good value for kids who go through kites like ours do!

title: Fun and pretty safe around kids/furniture but not the most stable
text:
Let me start off saying I very much appreciate the ring that protects the blades while also looking super cool when they glow. I have a similar sized mini drone that does not have this ring, and it is crashed into furniture and railings more times than I'd care to admit! This really is somewhat "crash proof", however only with side collisions. Our living room has a vaulted cathedral style ceiling, and if it hovers too high, the blade of the propeller can easily grind into the ceiling supports and crash / damage the blades. Thankfully it comes with extra propeller blades, but I think it should be called "Crash resistant" and not "crash proof"! But still a welcome feature. I also like how easy the emergency shut off to kill power is (something another drone I had was missing), and that it comes with two batteries! Often these mini drones only have enough power to last about 7-10 minutes at a time, but they take much longer than that to charge. Having a spare charging while you fly the other is a very welcome extra.
But on to the stuff I didn't like: I found that the drone sometimes has trouble being stable. It likes to rotate on its own, sometimes randomly and without warning. If you've ever flown one of these before, you know that knowing which direction is forward is crucial. A lot of these drones sort of "drift" over time, but the controller has trim keys you can use to correct for drifting and stabilize. But there's NOTHING you can do about rotation! If it starts rotating, the trim keys don't help at all! You can't stabilize it, you have to try counteracting the rotation and seeing if you just pray it stops. It really creates a challenge making it fly where you want it to. But if you're not the best pilot and sort of assume you'll be crashing into people/things anyway, this is a pretty good option because of the safety ring. Just don't fly it too high!

title: Great product, nails might be too small for some
text: My 10 year old daughter loves this set. Some products, such as the eyeliner, seem like the real deal, and you wouldn't know it is washable play variants. Her only complain, however, is the nail sets: her fingers are small but her thumb is wide, and she says basically that none of the nail things are the right size for her. Other than that, I'd recommend it for any child who is just starting to want their own makeup.

title: Poor quality control.
text: We were so excited to try this, but it won't power on. My kids were super bummed about that. It seems the battery compartment is poorly manufactured and the batteries might not be making contact. I could try to fix it with some wire and solder, but I'm so disappointed in the product so far I wish I could give it zero stars.

title: Great inexpensive kite!
text: I took this out with my kids today and it was really a ton of fun. They were able to assemble it mostly by themselves (a little bit of adult supervision required, but was pretty straight forward), and we had it in the air in no time. It's a generous size and shape, the eagle decoration made it fun for the younger kids, and it is actually pretty well made for the price. I've definitely had much worse quality kites for the price, so I'd say this is a decent deal for the money.

title: Fun but BE CAREFUL
text:
I have very mixed feelings about this game. First, it is REALLY FUN, and my kids and I were laughing really hard playing it. The drone taking off is really a lot of fun and cool to see, and even our little 3 year old who is too young to play was enamored by it and shrieking when it would lift off with little playing pieces inside! Really a lot of fun.
That being said, there are 3 caveats to be aware of:
1)I don't feel comfortable letting the kids play this alone. The drone comes crashing down sometimes and I want an adult or kid old enough to be able to catch it to avoid hurting anyone / furniture, or crashing so hard it cracks the plastic (a part of the drone siding already popped out, but I was able to push it back into place).

2) I feel like this game won't last very long. The pieces are VERY easily lost, as they end up being flung around the room as you play. Also, the drone lifting off bumps into the ceiling easily (thankfully we have cathedral ceilings in our living and had to move the game over to there, otherwise it would hit and come crashing down fast). It's only a matter of time before the plastic breaks or pieces get lost forever.

3) I dove to catch it on the way down after a particular round, and it hurt my finger. Nothing major, didn't hurt more than stubbing your toe on furniture or stepping on a lego- it has a safety to shut the propeller if it detects something in the way, but I was still surprised. I was fine, but one of my kids would have been crying if it happened to them.

My daughter actually suggested we try playing it outside next time, which might solve some of the issues- can't do damage to the house and everyone can duck for cover until it crashes into the grass. Wind might make it less fun though. HOWEVER- this was a TON OF FUN TO PLAY, so even with all those caveats, and even considering it might not last more than a few months in my household, I'd still consider it worth playing even for those few times. The look on their faces when the drone takes off is PRICELESS, and worth it even if you only get to play it once.

title: Love this swing!
text: My kids always love these in the park and I've been looking for one to use at home. This is similar, however it more consumer-grade and not as large and robust as the ones you find in park swing setups. That being set, I LOVE how adaptable this is, that you can hang it from trees with the included hardware, or mount it on a swingset or even indoors if you wanted! The pillow is a nice touch as well- all in all, I'm pleasantly surprised by how great of a swing this is and would totally recommend it!

title: Little one loves this!
text:
I have a daughter who loves animals but due to allergies we can't have pets in the home. This little toy, however, is wonderful! She loves playing with it, it is adorable and fun!
Her face lit up when she saw it for the first time. I'm very pleased with it and would recommend it.

title: Good idea, but the games are fakes
text:
This claims to be "retro/classic" games, and they all sort of are reminiscent of games I remember growing up... it feels like an emulator playing the classics (like I have on my phone) and they even make it look like the original Gameboy, but they're not the games I remember. They're cheap knock-offs. I'm guessing this company wanted to sell this device as an emulator for the classics but couldn't get the rights to the original games, so they modified them enough to be different games loosely based on the originals. For example, games like "plumbers" are clearly supposed to be a parody of Mario Bros, but none of them are the Mario Bros I remember and wanted to relive. I feel tricked. Also, a lot of the games aren't unique games but merely alternative versions, sometimes they feel like later levels of the same game, and many more aren't even really so interesting to play. The 500+ number is misleading. The UI is also cluttered as there's no way to sort the games and they don't appear to always be in alphabetical order, so you sort of have to scroll until you find the one you want which is annoying. You also can't remove the ones you don't want to clean it up either.
Honestly, I really REALLY wish it were just an emulator and you could use a USB cable or something to put your own ROM files like I have on my phone of the original games. And maybe even the ability to remove the ones I'm not interested in so the interface is cleaner. I like the physical layout of this with its physical buttons more than my phone, the second player controller is a treat, as well as the ability to plug this into a big screen (hello minivan entertainment system!), but these just aren't the games I want to play. I want the real retro classics. Not knock-offs. I feel tricked. This could be better if they gave us more control.

title: A lot of fun for kids to play!
text: Who doesn't want to be a Spy? My kids had a blast playing with all the stuff in here, and I had to politely ask them to stop fighting over who wears the spy getup when we leave the house now! There's a lot of fun stuff in the box, however one thing in particular, the black light flashlight, did not work out of the box. It requires small watch-sized batteries which were dead and we don't seem to have replacements here. I'm hoping to source some batteries for it eventually, but the kids were kind of bummed it wasn't ready to go out of the box. Something to be aware of. Otherwise, a ton of fun and the kids are really cute to see playing with it!

title: Fun blast from the past
text: I used to have similar styrofoam planes when I was a kid that I'd fly with my dad. These are a little smaller than the ones I had then (to be fair, I was smaller so my sense of scale might be off), but making these do loops really takes me back. Apparently you can change the flight pattern from loops to glider by adjusting the wings, but I've only managed to make it do loops. Throw it, it arcs up into the air, and does a summersault, swooping down and landing back towards the thrower. A lot of fun if you've got a nice back yard to play in. I like that there are multiple planes in this pack, but I wish it came with better instructions to explain how to fly it in different ways.

title: A great little bubble machine
text: This is smaller than a previous bubble machine we got, but it is quite mighty! I like that it comes with solution and everything you need to get started, just add batteries. The kids had a blast with this in the backyard. The only thing to keep in mind, however, is that the bubble solution is stored in an open tank, so if you tilt it over, it will spill everywhere. I think this is true of all bubble machines- we didn't think to take that into consideration when our youngest child wanted to carry it outside and did so sideways, spilling it all out by the front door! Just make sure to keep it level, and you'll have tons of fun!

title: Great project for a kid!
text: This is a wonderful project for a rainy day or when stuck at home during quarantine. My 8 year old daughter had a blast doing this with the help of her older 10 year old sister. They didn't need any parental help, it was completely on their own! As others mentioned, this isn't necessarily the highest quality pillow, but most kids will just take pride in the fact that they made it. It's really cute and I recommend it as a fun craft!

title: Fun toy!
text: If your kids love Rescue Heroes or just robot/mech toys, this is a great play set. Fisher Price doesn't disappoint with build quality and my kid really enjoys playing with it.  A good value for the money.

title: Tons of fun! But no trigger
text: This is a great way to cool off in the heat with the kids! My little ones loved how easy it was to replenish after using up the tank (the entire back opens up so it fills much faster), and the triple-nozzle front was a blast (literally! ha). One thing I didn't realize beforehand, however, is that it works entirely by pump action. That is, unlike a super soaker or other water pistol that builds pressure with the pump and then releases with a trigger, the pump is the entire firing mechanism, and the "trigger" is just for show (doesn't do anything). Pulling back on the pump fires the water, and the strength is adjusted  by how hard/fast you pull back. My older kids were able to figure that out, but my youngest (3 years old) found it disappointing. He likes the trigger kind because it is easy for him to fire, and with this he wasn't able to figure out the dexterity to make it shoot very far. For what it is, it works and is fun, but I do sort of wish it had a trigger that wasn't just there for looks.

title: Fun!
text:
This is great on a hot day in the backyard! You'll need a bucket of water to fill it up if you don't have a swimming pool. Our house is having AC problems so this was a welcome distraction on a hot day for the kids to go run outside and cool off with!
I wish they held more water at a time, but they are fun to use. A good value for the price.

title: Perfect for curious kids!
text:
This came just in time for spring during quarantine! Our little girls love the outdoors and catching bugs, I wish I had photographed their eyes when they opened up this kit. It's got so many fun things for them to use, they instantly ran into the back yard with it while my wife and I did some gardening. It kept them busy for hours! The items in it seem to be of high quality, and we're overall impressed with the kit.
If you've got kids who like to explore the outdoors, this could make a cute gift. I recommend it.

title: Travel size fun
text: This is a small game set, it was actually a little smaller than we expected, but this is still a great rendition of the classic Chinese Checkers game. My kids really enjoyed playing with it over the weekend and the fact that it is designed to be travel friendly is actually pretty neat. This is a good product, just don't surprised if it is small enough to fit in a purse pocket.

title: Disappointing. The other Marvel Nerf sets are so much better.
text:
We love Marvel and we love Nerf, so this series is a match made in heaven. I was so excited about this.
We got a chance to try both the Black Panther and Iron Man versions from this set as well, and I have to say I'm glad I tried those first. They are fun and work well, with the Iron Man being my favorite. This glove, however, is very disappointing. Like the other Marvel firing gloves, you have to load it by pulling back on a mechanism and then perform a motion to fire (Black Panther requires a power slash move, Iron man pull your hand back to reveal repulsors, etc). This one is supposed to fire with a forward motion like a power punch, but it just won't fire without some help on the mechanism. My daughters (who were most excited for this one) weren't able to make it fire at all, my oldest son and I can sort of make it work if we push forward on the firing mechanism with our other hand as we move forward, but there's no way it is supposed to be this complicated. I think the design is faulty. I'd strongly recommend some of the other shooting gloves in this set. This one is a dud.

title: Awesome addition to Marvel Nerf set!
text:
We love Marvel and we love Nerf. So, obviously I had to take the opportunity to bring these into our home and try them out!
The glove is really nice and easy to assemble, and feels really cool to swing around with even without the dart firing part. I dare anyone to put it on and not get into character even for a moment. The firing part is even cooler- you pull back the spring loaded mechanism to load it, then mime a cat slash (flick wrist downward) and it gives a satisfying firing sound that jettisons two darts across the room. The only thing I don't like about it however is that there are 3 darts included and two fire at a time. You could load one at a time if you want, but it feels like they should have included an even number of them. Also, there is no place to store the additional darts. The Iron Man version of this set also comes with 3 darts, but has a place to store all of them on the glove as you lead them one at a time. Firing two with this and then awkwardly holding the third seems like they didn't think it through all the way. But, it's still fun, especially if you love the Black Panther character.

title: So much fun!
text:
My kids love the Marvel films and nerf darts, so this is a match made in heaven! This toy is a ton of fun, you pull your hand back like Iron Man does in the films and comics, and an energy blast in the form of a nerf dart flies through the air!
It is very satisfying to see and hear, and in my head I practically hear the sound effect from the movie every time. I see there are other similar shooters for other Marvel characters, I may have to get them all so we don't fight over this one. Yes, I said we. Adult parents included!

title: Unique twist on drones, fun for beginners too!
text:
[[VIDEOID:8a11b7441ed851da9934dc27ecfce06e]] We own quite a few drones in our household, from toy practice ones to racing ones, to camera enabled, to prosumer DJI models, and beyond. And I have to say, this is the most fun we've had with one. Aside from the standard controller, the "gesture mode" means you can brush your hands in font of proximity sensors and send the drone in a specific direction. This makes it possible to play sort of catch game, as players can pass it from person to person without even touching it, just by waving their hands in the right spot. This mode also helps prevent collisions as it will automatically move away from walls if the proximity sensor detects one getting too close. That combined with the shielded propeller design make this a very good first drone for those new to the whole thing.
There are some caveats- while you can start the drone hands free (see video) you still need the controller around. Enabling gesture mode, for example, only seemed to work for me with the button on the remote. While I could put my hand underneath it to tell it to go UP, there was no sensor on the top to go back down, so I need the controller again to lower it and also to eventually land it. Those are minor however, compared to how great and unique of a concept this drone is. I highly recommend it!

title: A cheap Skip It!
text:
I grew up with the classic Skip It toy being advertised on TV (the jingle still pops into my head at the oddest times). This toy is basically a modern inexpensive version of that: Attach the loop to one leg, start it spinning via kick and skip over it with the other leg, sort of like a one-legged jump rope. The inductive lights are a cool new touch, however playing with it outside in direct sunlight the lights are not as noticeable.
This toy isn't quite the same quality as higher end skip toys (I recall the Skip It being pretty durable), but for the price I'd say its still a good deal. My kids used it all afternoon and loved it. My wife and I, meanwhile, had a trip down memory lane as we showed them what to do and got a good workout at the same time!

title: Love it, but be careful with helipad
text:
My 3 year old adores airplanes and this has quickly become a favorite toy of his. The only issue is, there's a helipad that you place atop the cockpit area for the helicopter to land on, and this is an odd placement for it. It blocks the doors from opening/closing, which means you can't play with it and keep that on at the same time. This would normally be such a minor inconvenience that it isn't worth mentioning, but when you're 3 years old you want to "have your cake and eat it too", as they say.
That being said, we just sort of took the helipad out of the set and he's back to playing with it frustration-free. I'd gladly give this 5 stars if it weren't for that odd design choice, but it is still a great toy that my kid loves playing with!

title: Fits American Girl dolls perfectly
text: I was a little nervous about buying outfits from a third party, as they don't always fit the authentic American Girls dolls as well as the real ones. But I'm happy to say, these fit quite well and my little girls love it and are very happy! A great selection of outfits for a great price, I'd recommend this to anyone who wants to treat their little one to some new doll clothes.

title: Cheap and plentiful- great for parties!
text: I have a kid with a birthday coming up in a month, and for the price, this is a perfect set of goodie bag prizes for the party. The stuff is the sort of quality you'd expect for the task- cheap and plentiful, not exactly high quality stuff you expect them to keep for very long. For that, it is really perfect and exactly what we wanted / expected!

title: Really fun! But careful with the chargers
text:
[[VIDEOID:c198354da4ee3e3e44cb1b9bad7731a9]] Let me start off by saying my kids LOVE these. The fact that there's 2 in the package makes it a ton of fun to play together, and although the music is a little bit annoying it can be turned off, and the wacky movements and lights are a TON of fun! See the video for more info.
Since recording that video, however, I noticed that one of the cars wasn't charging. When I went to go unplug it to check it out, I noticed the charging cable had started to melt. I think it shorted out and started overheating, possibly because my kids had plugged it in to charge and weren't careful about it. The other wire still works fine and we are able to charge it one at a time without a problem. I'd like to see if I can get that wire replaced because they are still tons of fun to play with.

title: Very cool looking!
text:
These are really cool looking cards. They have a water resistant plastic feeling finish which catches the light in such interesting ways. It almost seems like the shapes dance when light passes over it. The rear of the cards have $100 bill patterns which just add to the appeal of this deck.
They aren't very easy to spread for fans or certain types of card tricks. They do shuffle well though so they are great to actually play cards with.

title: Great for kids who love planes
text: My 3 year old has an obsession with airplanes. His eyes literally lit up when he saw this package! So many different kinds of vehicles, from helicopters to bombers to jets... some really funky looking ones too! They all pull back and then propel themselves forward like the classic pull-back-car toys, but thanks to the wingspan it is pretty easy to make them collide if facing each other. In fact, my son and I did that a few times today and had the planes run into each other, where they then spun in a circle with their wings interlocked until the wound up energy was spent. My kid's reaction? "Look they are dancing!" Priceless. Thank you Amazon for offering this amazing set of toys. A perfect gift for any kid who is into aerial vehicles.

title: Generous size and cool colors!
text:
This is yet another variation of the "Boogie Board" drawing tablet. If you are not familiar with the concept, it is NOT a digital tablet, but essentially a reusable drawing tool much like a whiteboard. It starts off as an opaque black surface that reveals a different color underneath with pressure. So you can draw on it using the included pen, a fingernail, or anything with enough pressure really, and then erase it all at once with the erase button on the bottom. The only electronics involved is a battery that "zaps" the display back to opaque to start over. This battery should last years as it only gets used when erasing for a split second.
I actually like this one better than some of our other ones as the contrast between the black and revealed color is quite high. Some of the inexpensive Boogie Board clones lack contrast and can be hard to see sometimes, but that is not the case here. It also seems to have a multi-colored background, so as you draw or write, it feels like the color is changing (really it is just revealing a different part of the material behind the LCD). I also really like the size of it, as our other drawing tablets were small whereas this one feels closer to a sheet of paper. My 12 year old son actually finds this comfortable for using as a scratch pad for his math homework, which is a great environmentally friendly alternative to scrap paper. And my younger kids like drawing pictures on it or playing games like tick-tack-toe.
You do have to be a little bit careful about resting your hand on it as it seems even that amount of pressure will leave a mark, and sadly you can't erase part of a picture, you can only erase the entire thing in one shot with the button. But this is true of all similar drawing pads due to how it works, so that is no fault of this product. As far as the Boogie Board clones go, this is my favorite so far.

title: Such cool cards
text: We own 2 other decks by Joker and the Thief, and they are all super high quality. This one is no exception- the durability of the cards is top notch, and they are easy to shuffle and slide (and particularly smooth for card tricks!). The artwork is also amazing, as usual. I happen to think their Red and Gold deck is the best looking deck they make, but it is nice to have options and this one is really interesting looking in a more subdued blue hues way. If you are on the fence and appreciate high quality cards, I highly recommend you give these a shot. They are awesome!

title: A must have classic for any track builder!
text:
[[VIDEOID:1b129aad0ac7875fbc5ea4943fb19eaf]] This is a throwback to a time before Hot Wheels starting cheating with battery operated motors. I recall building tracks with friends (before I was an adult obviously... yeah...) that used momentum, gravity, pulleys and rubber bands to make it to the end of an elaborate track, but modern sets seem to fall back on electricity to give your car a "bump" to continue. I honestly thought they had stopped making the classic mechanical "kicker", I am SO HAPPY to see this for sale here!
To those who think this is a set itself- it is a part, a tool to make a more elaborate hot wheels Rube Goldberg style setup. It is powered by rubber bands, plastic hinges and pure imaginative MAGIC.
My kids (2, 7 and 9) spent hours with it this evening, making elaborate gravity loops leading to this KICKER to fling it up over a jump at the end. We had to clean it up and put it away, but they're already talking about how we're going to use it this weekend to something bigger. I love seeing their mechanical imagination juices flowing, and I imagine this is what I looked like when I was... um... younger... playing with similar sets. Thank you Hot Wheels for continuing the fun into the next generation!
What's that? No, I'm totally not staying up and building a track in the middle of the night right now... why?

title: The more the merrier!
text:
This is our third giant blow up bubble ball in the household, and honestly I could see us going for more in the future! They are insanely fun to roll down hills inside of, but the real fun comes when you have sets of them to run into each other. My kids loved our original one, but they used to fight over turns and there was only so much you can do at a time. With two of them, you can run into each other and play games that make it exponentially more exciting. With 3, let's just say 2 kids + an adult = insane outdoor fun!
It seems pretty durable so far, although I'd avoid any sharp terrain or thorn bushes. They are definitely more fun if you can afford more than one, but even one is awesome if you've got a hill you can use.

title: Love this premium card brand
text: My son is a card trick / playing card enthusiast, and my entire household really appreciates a quality durable deck. We own some other "Joker and the Thief" brand cards, and honestly have been really impressed with the brand in general. This deck is no different: The quality is top notch, you can really feel the difference in your fingers. But the design on this one is truly outstanding. The way the gold and red reflects makes the deck look premium. I have no complaints at all and totally recommend it.

title: A great size quad! But weird shut off...
text:
We have quite a few quadcopters in our house between my son and I- everything from micro drones that fit in the palm of your hand to foldables and RC car drone combos to full sized DJI Phantoms. So we have a bit of experience with these sort of things, and I have to say I really like this one.
The size is larger than the micro drones but smaller than the RC car combos and a fraction of the pro level ones. This makes it lean enough that we can fly it around indoors but substantial enough to hover and hold it's position properly (the micro drones sometimes shift when a fan turns on LOL). It does all the standard tricks a small Made-in-China drone can be expected to perform, including 360-degree flips, and even includes a surprisingly half decent camera that connects via their app from the play/app store. I mean, its obviously nothing close to my Phantom's camera, and you'd only ever use this for fun and not if you ever want to look at the pictures/video ever again... but it's probably one of the best cheap Chinese drone cameras I've seen yet. Sort of reminds me of a low end cell phone or dash cam in quality, whereas our other cheap drones have horribly grainy/noisy and pixely images with totally wrong and fluctuating color and blown out highlights/darks in any lighting (and one of them even only displays the camera upside-down for some reason- don't ask). The bottom line is, this one is NONE of those things, it's actually pretty decent for a hobby toy.
The ONLY thing I don't like about it, however, is the emergency shut off. Every drone, especially toy ones, need to have one of these features. Think of it like an ABORT button, that you press if something goes wrong such as getting too close to a person or ceiling fan blade, etc, or sometimes in our case if it got stuck somewhere and is about to grind off its propellers into a metal shelf. It is supposed to immediately shut all motors and allow the drone to fall from its position. But the shut off on this remote requires you to press and hold the button for a couple of seconds for it to stop. I thought maybe we were doing it wrong so I checked the instructions again, and sure enough it says "press and hold for a long time". I'm including a shot of the manual page, I couldn't believe it until I saw it. That's a horrible idea for an emergency and would likely be too late if you have to hold the button for a while hoping it stops before the drone damages itself or worse, a person.
So, I want to give this drone 5 stars, I feel like as a drone it is awesome and fantastic. Flies nicely, has great features and a fun camera, but that shut off is a design flaw worth removing at least one star.

title: AWESOME! But you might need more than one...
text:
We have one of these from last summer, and my kids have a blast in them... but it gets old quick when only one at a time can play.
