It gets a LOT MORE FUN when 2 or more kids can put these one and run into each other. The neighbors come by and want to play too... we may need to get more! Thanks to a slight hill between our yard and our neighbors, this is contributed to some truly epic outdoor laughs!
I've taken a few tumbles myself down the hill with this on, and it was AWESOME. If you haven't tried one yet, I recommend it. And if you can afford more than one, I REALLY recommend it!

title: This has kept my kids busy for DAYS!
text:
This is awesome. They are pull-back style cars (pull them back and release to propel them forward), with a spring loaded demolition mode upon impact (that is, the bumper is a button that released the spring and shatters the car into pieces). You can then reassemble it, or even mix and match with other cars for cool color combos! There is a pin if you want to lock them in place and not smash on impact, and they are actually quite large- bigger than I expected (bigger than an adult's hand). And they come with 6 in a pack! Honestly, I would say any one of those features would be something cool to talk about, but this toy is all of the above, and that's plenty to keep a bunch of curious kids playing with it for hours to days on end!
The only issue is that it took a while for my kids to figure out how the parts go back together, but once they mastered it, it's been pretty easy. Don't get discouraged the first time if you can't get it to work, take your time, it'll start to make sense.

title: Fun and cool, but with caveats
text: My son has become something of a middle-school card shark, and this is the second set of waterproof cards he's wanted to try.  They are very cool, and the waterproof part seems to hold up so far (we tried purposely getting it wet, it's just plastic so no effect). The only issues I've noticed are that the black on black print can only been seen with good light. It's reflective black print, in limited light I can see this being difficult to play with. My son doesn't see that as a caveat, however- he thinks the reflective print makes it really cool and special and doesn't have a hard time seeing it at all. We do both agree on the other caveat though: half the deck came out of the box slightly warped. I have no explanation, see the attached picture to illustrate. They still shuffle and you can still play with them, but sadly they have trouble lying flat as a result. Still worth at least 4 stars, not perfect but very cool.

title: For fun by the water!
text:
I've had the opportunity to try out two styles from this brand. They are both excellent. These are stiff plastic cards which can be shuffled and dealt like normal cards but be immune to water damage. My son has recently taken up an interest in cards, and took these on a vacation to a water park. No problems with spills from drinks or playing by the pool, these cards are practically indestructible!
They also look really cool, thanks to the black background coloring. One of his friends was so impressed with them he's ordering a deck too. Very cool.

title: Best birthday present ever!
text: I have a daughter who just turned 7 and loves science and building. This was the perfect gift for her- so much better than other building toys or another science experiment kit. You can use the tools and parts in so many different ways, it really keeps her absorbed and interested. I really enjoy seeing her mind process and her creativity come out with it. The kit appears to be of very high quality, I was impressed with how it is laid out when you remove the parts and the instructions were easy enough for her to follow with some help from a sibling to read. Really impressed and really like it!

title: Can slide where regular sleds can't
text:
My front yard has a slight enough of a slope that a traditional sled gets stuck with soft snow but a tube like this makes it all the way down. This was a blast to use, my kids really loved it, until one of them accidentally rode over some branches which tore a small hole in the bottom. Thankfully the box came with some patches so we were able to cover it up and take it back out. But if it happens 2 more times, we will be out of patches, so be careful where you ride it.
The logo is kind of cheesy... I think I would have preferred a tube without any writing on it, but at least it makes it easy to claim which tube is yours if you're in a group ("mine is the one with the cheesy 'I am on fire' text written on it!").
Still, deserves at least 4 stars for being a good time, which is what it is meant to be.

title: A stylish take on the classic
text: This is an interesting style twist on the classic Rubik's cube. Traditionally the cubes were black segments with colored faces. This product, however, offers all black looks with colored outlines. It looks sharp and futuristic, and the faces of each side have that distinct carbon-fiber pattern look that just makes it cooler.  It isn't the smoothest "speed cube" out there, however- there are some I've used that feel so well oiled that they spin freely with minimal effort. This, my son pointed out, wasn't as smooth as his fastest speed cube, however it is still pretty decent. It definitely looks better than any other ones we have. The muted outline color look is very cool.

title: So much fun! For the first couple of days...
text:
[[VIDEOID:8a35051fba3b622e613e552275a81a53]] This is a great starter drone, in theory. I have flown many of these and my son wanted to try one to get started with. He picked it up really quickly and together we were able to fly it around the house indoors without hitting anything. The camera is gimmicky at best, but for the price I'd say get it for the drone flight fun and forget the camera.
UNTIL... within 2 days of owning it, something seemed to go wrong with the height sensor (barometer?), and it not only wouldn't hold the correct height like it did the day before, but suddenly it shot straight UP. No pressing down on the joystick seems to change anything. Its as if the unit felt like it was falling and needed to compensate by flying more aggressively upwards. It hit the ceiling, and we promptly hit the kill switch. I took a look at it, pulled off the propellers to look, and tried again. Same thing - it shot straight UP. Hit the ceiling. I tried cleaning any hair/debris from the blades and again- straight up until it hit. But this time, it started making a funny noise. Upon closer inspection I found one of the pins that the propeller sits on has been bent. I don't know if this was caused by it going straight up or if it caused it, but the drone has been grounded for now. You can see in the attached video how when that pin is spun, it tilts forward and back, rather that the other pins which spin in place.
It is possibly that I just got a dud and others would love this, I wouldn't mind trying it again and seeing if I have a different outcome. It did work really well for the first 2 days, and I really like that it not only has a replaceable battery but comes with 2 additional batteries as well! Flight times are usually small on these things so having many extra batteries ready to go is useful. If it hadn't gone nuts and shot upwards everytime, I'd give this thing 5 stars. I'm going to see what I can about sourcing a replacement or additional unit and come back to update this review if it turns out I had a lemon.

title: Smash the blocks!
text: My almost-three-year-old loves running the train down the track into the blocks which ends in a satisfying collision. It is just enough to excite him without making a mess (there are only three blocks after all). The problem is, there is little room for creative play beyond that- the track has some ups and downs but you can't really rearrange it in too many ways, and without any curves you can't really do anything other than a straight line. But for a kid around this age, it is a blast. We started adding more things to the tower (like legos and magnet tiles) to create a more epic crash at the end of the tunnel, and he laughs every time.

title: Fun in all kinds of ways!
text:
This is really interesting toy that can be all sorts of things. The pieces, when assembled, can not only act as a large playing board, but also a sort of floor mat for a kid's room, as it is made of the sort of soft rubbery material you often find play areas made of. My kids also found that they could create 3-dimensional shapes with them by connecting some at 90 degree vertical angles, making cubes and towers instead of just 2-D floor maps.
As far as the games- Tic Tac Toe was popular in our household, although it required attaching multiple pieces of the same color together to create 9 larger squares. It adds an interesting twist to gameplay by requiring the pieces to be tossed successfully onto the square you want. Another required skill than just strategy to win the game! Checkers was fun too, but reaching across the board can be difficult for smaller players to do without accidentally moving other pieces. But honestly, both of these games paled in comparison to my kids just loving the board pieces and having fun treating it like giant toy blocks (at one point they made "shoes" by creating elongated cubes they could put their feet into and slide around the floor with).
I'd say it's a good buy, but for reasons other than just checkers and 3-in-a-row.

title: Great addition to our tree!
text: We have a set of trees that we use for a hammock, monkey bars and a tire swing. Our younger kids have expressed wanting a normal swing as well, and this really does the trick. It is a very cute pink color, and seems extremely sturdy hanging from the monkey bars. I really like that it has a coated chain for their hands so they don't have to touch the harsh metal (which hopefully won't rust, but when it does they wont have to touch it!), and I really REALLY like the attachment clasp on the top of the chain. Made it really simple and secure to hang. If you want to add a cute swing to your backyard or existing swing set, I think this is a good choice!

title: Great set even not for travel!
text:
My kids have just started getting really into Chess, especially after all of our attempts to ween them off video games. But, unlike video games, board game pieces tend to make a mess and get lost. That's why I particularly like THIS set. The magnetic pieces are good for travel for obvious reasons, but they're even better for HOME, especially when you have smaller siblings who may try to grab the board now and then! Having it fold in half for storage also means you can keep all your pieces somewhere and not lose them.
These aren't knew, I had a similar set growing up 30+ years ago, but this design is classic and timeless, just like the game itself. Every household should have one in my opinion!

title: Not compatible with other magnet tiles
text: These are knockoffs of the popular magnet tile building toys. I've bought other third party clone products before and have been happy with them, but these are sadly not at all compatible with the other sets. They are smaller physically, and don't seem to have as strong magnetic properties. The colors are nice, and they do have some interesting shapes and pieces that my other sets don't, but as a whole I'd prefer the other product clones over this one. It isn't a bad product if you intend to only use it and not mix with other similar sets, but why would you if you know there are sets that are compatible with each other to build a larger set in the future?

title: Beautiful and excellent quality
text:
This is our second Joker and the Thief set we've tried, and I have to say these are incredibly high end and have a really nice finish and touch to them. They aren't cheap, but if you want the durability of fancy cards for tricks and smooth shuffle movement, these are a lot better than your average name-brand card (*cough* bicycle *cough*). I really like the artwork on them as well they are a beautiful set.
My son actually pointed out that the other Joker and Thief set we got shuffled a little smoother than this one- this is more of a matte finish rather than the slippery smooth finish of the other deck we got. But you can only tell if comparing them side by side. This deck on its own right is incredible and well worth the money if you're into cards.

title: Really cool!
text: My son has recently taken up physical card tricks, and is very picky about his cards. These have an excellent finish to them  that makes it almost slippery smooth, yet stays put when you want it to. It allows him to smoothly perform in ways that regular old Bicycle cards don't.  The graphics on this are also REALLY wild and cool. It's a really nice high quality set, and I highly recommend them.

title: Still a classic!
text:
This is a modern edition of a classic game. I remember playing Upwords when I was younger and I always found it more interesting than Scrabble. I like the creativity in taking an existing word and changing it by stacking letter tiles, and now that my kids are old enough to read and spell, I'm going to introduce this game to a new generation!
I do notice that the build quality has been somewhat lowered compared to the original game tiles as I remember them, but I think that is true of board games in general. Many other recent editions of classic games (Monopoly, etc) seem to be somewhat shoddier as well, which just makes me sound old when I say "they don't make this like they used to!". Thankfully it doesn't detract from a great family game experience. If you don't have this classic, I recommend it!

title: High quality set, interestingly it did NOT come with instructions
text:
Melissa & Doug are known for their high end children's products, and this is no exception! The entire set, down to the solid wooden box it comes in for storage, feels like premium quality built to outlast your kids. I was excited to give this to our girls, but I found it interested that there were not any instructions included. I guess the game of Jacks is considered so well known already that much like a deck of playing cards requires no instruction, neither should this.
However, it turns out my kids weren't particularly familiar with it so I had to teach them. Good bonding times, but make sure first that you know how to play so that you aren't surprised when you get it!

title: This is a high quality toy!
text:
These are surprisingly well built plastic toys. I guess I shouldn't be surprised, they do have official CAT branding on them, and I'd guess only a toy that meets their high standards of quality would get that. The parts move so kids can actually full the buckets with things and have it lift/dump/etc, and the grooved wheels make a satisfying rumble when you push it along a hard wood floor.
It sort of reminds me of the metal toy trucks we had when I was a kid, you know the ones that would last forever because they were metal? This isn't metal so it is actually less dangerous and more child friendly, but I'd be surprised if this doesn't last as long. The quality of the material is top notch. And of course, our 2 year old son LOVES them!

title: Good game, with some minor flaws
text:
This is a very cute concept and something out-of-the-ordinary for a board game! The object of the game is to make it out with the least amount of goo on your shoe. This is represented by actual pieces of putty that you place on the board and squish with your pawn as you land on a square (thus sticking the goo to your, erm, shoe).
My kids really enjoyed it, but I can't help feeling like there are some design flaws that could have been prevented. For example, the spinner needs to be deconstructed to put away in the box. The way the board folds (see picture), the crease is over the spinner area, and with the bars on the spinner (which I like, as it looks like a playground toy) won't fit, which means you have to totally take that apart and rebuilt it each time. On that note, it isn't much of a spinner at all, but just a wheel. There is no clicker or arrow that sticks out to slow it down as it spins... it basically spins until momentum from your push wears out, sort of like spinning a top. It takes a while to finally stop on its own, which makes the game feel like it is moving slowly. I was very tempted to just stop it manually a few times, but that might bring up the possibility of cheating.
Meanwhile, I wish the goo had more colors, or at least colors that matched the shoes in the game. I can say on the positive note, the goo is very kid friendly!
My daughter lost one of the colors and it turns out she was SITTING on it and it was all stuck in her dress. I suddenly had flashbacks of when silly putty got stuck on her clothing and bed and we had to toss them both because it never came off... but this stuff comes off! It easily rolls into balls with your fingers and comes right off clothing in the process. So, definitely some extra points for that! I just wish the game board and spinner were designed a little better, that would make it a lot more fun to play (and put away!).

title: Beer Pong meets Battleship!
text:
We've only had this a few days so far, but my kids love it so far! They and their neighborhood friends were playing almost non-stop this entire weekend. It's a pretty unique concept and not at all what I expected coming from the original battleship: Rather than the game of strategy (and sometimes just luck!) that the traditional battleship is, this is mostly a game of skill. There is still some strategy in how you align your boats, but rather than try to determine where the other player's position is, you can see their board and have to toss one of the included ping-pong balls into the holes. Land a ball in all the boat's places, and you've sunk their ship! It is definitely reminiscent of beer pong in skillset, or perhaps one of those arcade games that require you to land a ball in a colored cup. You definitely need more space to play since there will be balls bouncing around if/when you miss, but it is a lot of fun. A creative twist on a classic game!
One thing that is a little strange to me however, is the advertising. The listing for this product says "Nostalgic tabletop gameplay meets interactive digital content for an immersive gaming experience". There's nothing digital about this, let alone interactive digital and immersive. It's a pretty fun analog pick-up-and-play game, which is what I like about it actually, but it was hard to determine what we were getting before we tried it.

title: Cool spinning action!
text:
This is an interesting set in that it is more like an action figure or top-based game than a Lego build. Once it is all together, the figure gets launched into a spinning maneuver which can then knock over other pieces. Traditionally with Legos, at least half the fun is in the building of a set. With this, it feels more like you got an action figure that needs to be assembled before you play with it. It builds really quickly since there aren't so many parts, so that's actually a pretty good thing for those who want to jump right to the playing part.
I have to admit, it looks like a lot of fun, but might disappoint those looking for more building-style lego play. I personally like it, it is different and cool.

title: A lot of fun for fans of the HP franchise
text: For those not familiar, this is yet another Lego set designed to recreate a fan favorite scene from a movie (or book, I suppose, but so far these scenes appear to mostly be modeled after the movie versions). I've owned a few of these before from different franchises, in particular Star Wars, and really found the character pieces more interesting than the scene it came with to build. So, like some others here, I was initially interested in this set for the Harry Potter character pieces. However I was pleasantly surprised to see how cool and detailed the scene actually is. This is a fun set and I highly recommend it for any enthusiastic fan of Harry Potter.

title: Great for bubble machines!
text: We tried this in our motorized bubble machine and it has been great! We have kids young enough to accidentally knock over the bubble machine frequently, which means we've wasted a lot of bubble solution in the past. I love having 64 ounces of solution handy to refill if/when it happens next. The funnel top is a great addition too, and of course the wand works well for straight-up blowing bubbles the old fashioned way.

title: Perfect for younger kids
text:
This transformer toy is super simplistic. But that is on purpose- this is designed to be fun for younger kids or whoever might otherwise not have the dexterity to transform a complicated object with moving parts into a robot. Like my 3-year-old, for example (he loves both robots and cars). It is easy for him to transform it since it requires only a top bar to move which then automatically pushes the rest of the moving parts into place, and vice versa to transform back.
The wheels spin when in car mode, and it is able to stand on two legs in robot mode. This is a great starter for the world of Transformers.

title: Love that they are making a comeback
text:
My mom saved some Polly Pocket toys from decades ago, and they are a real treat for my kids to play with when we come visit. As you can imagine, I'm thrilled to see Polly making a comeback in this modern version, as are the kids! This is the second modern set we've gotten for them to play with, and they are just as ecstatic to have their own Polly Pockets as I expected.
Honestly, if I compare this to the original ones, I think it is fair to say that they "don't make 'em like they used to". The originals had incredibly fine detail that seems missing on the newer generations. Its not that the new ones are bad, the kids absolutely LOVE them, but they seem to have cut some corners in the construction versus the original toys. That's ok with me, I'm just so happy this toy is making a comeback so that we can buy them again for the next generations!

title: Range from easy to near-impossible!
text:
What's great about this set is that each puzzle has its own level of difficulty. The classic Rubik's 3x3 style cube is here, as is a somewhat simpler 2x2 and a surprisingly easy pyramid. My 11 year old son can solve the pyramid one in about 15 seconds, which always seems to impress his friends at first. It turns out it is actually a lot easier than the classic 3x3 cube, but you wouldn't know without experiencing it. Those two are great for building confidence and then moving on to the classic and then the more difficult ones.
The last two puzzles are very difficult- we haven't solved them yet. I'm sure they can be done and it is just a matter of time, but that's what makes this set so great: Anyone on any skill level can find one they can do, and find ones that will challenge them. Great for a family with multiple kids on different levels.

title: A great box of projects for my daughters and friends
text:
This made a great group project for my girls and their friends during those days between camp and school. The durability of the actual products were not necessarily the highest quality, they kind of look and feel cheap, but that isn't the point of a set like this. This is designed to be a fun activity, and it successfully entertained my daughters (age 6 and 9) for hours along with some neighbors who came to play as well.
So five stars for the price and doing what I believe it is designed to do: be a fun project.

title: Really fun game!
text:
We got the Mario version of the game, and my kids would play this all day if I let them.
Just to get this out of the way in case it isn't obvious, there is nothing inherently about Mario in this game nor is there anything about any of the other themed franchises (Harry Potter, Marvel, etc) in their version. They are all the same matching game but with different themed cards and stickers.
That being said, I have never played Top Trumps before and at first I thought the instructions made it sound like a rather complicated twist on a classic matching game. However my kids really picked it up and then explained to ME how to play! It really is fun and the whole cube thing makes it more interesting than just another board or card game. I particularly liked our Mario version as a fan of Nintendo, but it seems they have licensed almost any popular franchise so pick the one you like best!

title: Fancy! And Cool! Everyone here loves it!
text:
When we opened this box, everyone in my household was wowed by it. It's HUGE, much bigger than any magic set we've bought previously, and comes with a lot of very high quality tricks. The classics are here, such as the cups and balls, but instead of flimsy red-colored cups like the kind I had growing up, these are majestic looking curved goblets- the kind you'd expect someone being paid to perform at a party would have. My kids have been obsessed with it ever since it arrived, taking turns learning a trick and trying to wow us and the neighbor's kids. It's really adorable and has sparked a creative interest in learning how to perform competitively.
Really a wonderful set and very highly recommended!

title: You're the one...you make bath time so much fun!
text:
My kids ADORE these. We filled the bathtub with them and my kids had a blast, laughing and playing with them. In fact, one of my kids who usually fights with us at bath time actually was asking when she could take one already. Don't expect big ducks like the kind Ernie uses from Sesame Street- these are small individually, but they DO quack / squeak upon being squeezed.
Just be careful about taking them out of the bath, since if they were squeezed inside of it they will retain some of the water. One of my kids brought one downstairs where we have cheap flooring that is sensitive to water damage, and we found the ducky leaking water from the bath. Leaving water inside these for a long time isn't a good idea anyway long term, so make sure you squeeze them out again before storing after use in the bath. Otherwise, they are super fun and cute!

title: Really cute toy for kids
text:
My girls love this. I mean, come on- its a puppy in a carrying bag purse! What little girl could deny such cuteness?? The dog toy itself is soft and plush and squishy, all the things a stuffed toy should be! The bag is cute and seems well made enough to use as a bag for other things as well. One of my daughters actually used it when she decided to play school, putting pencils and mini notebooks in. It's quite adorable. I'm not sure where the puppy was during this game, but I'd like to think he was sitting in a chair as a furry student somewhere.
One thing to note- my kids took the puppy outside for a bit and he fell in some twigs/leaves. The fur is like glue on little pieces of leaves and yard debris. It took a lot of effort to get him clean again, so be careful getting him dirty!

title: Great tricks! But some of the gimmick parts are flimsy
text:
I'd like to start by pointing out the tricks in this box are great and my son LOVES them. They are creative and clever and he likes to practice them, especially the card based ones. But some of the individual tricks are very flimsy and won't last very long. One of the items, a retractable line you attach to something (and make it "disappear" by having the line retract quickly) didn't work after one use. Much like a tape measure that got stuck, it wouldn't wind itself back up all the way. My son being somewhat of an engineer in his head, decided to try and fix it by taking it apart.
Let's just say that didn't go well, and that particular trick has been disposed of.
I'd be inclined to give it 2 stars, except that my son actually still really likes the set despite this. And it has encouraged him to play more off electronic devices like tablets, so it definitely deserves at least 3 stars for that. I just wish I could say all the tricks were high quality.

title: Great motivator for bath time!
text:
I figured these would be fun for my kids during bath time, and I wasn't wrong. They draw much like crayons, even when wet, yet wash away easily leaving no residue behind. Some colors seem to work better than others. The red, for example, comes out bold and strong, whereas the blue needed a bit more pressure to draw with, while the yellow was just plain hard to see (granted, our tub is pink so it isn't the greatest color for yellow to be fair... but even on white, I feel like the yellow would be difficult to see).
The best part? My kids LOVE bath time now. One of them actually asked me if I could wake her up an hour early to go take another bath and play with them before school. And this is a kid who I usually have to bribe to go in!

title: So much fun!
text:
[[VIDEOID:7cc971363a284b7d3b621443aac8a13e]] This is a TON of fun, and has been inflated for over a week without losing any air. I'll admit I was slightly concerned when it came without much in the form of instructions or labels (there's a paper with poorly typed tips and warnings, and another with warranty info). Seems like a no-frills made in China product. But I have to admit, once we pumped it up, the kids haven't stopped playing with it.
The air valve is a standard sized one (I believe it is called a Boston Valve), so we were able to use a pump from an air mattress to easily inflate it. It took a while to get it fully inflated, although the paper that comes with it warns not to inflate entirely - there should be some give so it can bounce without putting too much pressure on popping it. There are straps inside to adjust to your height and then worn like a backpack, while there are handles in front of you to hold onto. It is pretty self explanatory but it would have been nice to have detailed instructions about, for example, how to tell which way is face up. You'll figure it out without them, but the experience would have been better when using the first time.
Something to note: it is IMMENSELY more fun if you have a hill to roll down. Just running around and falling over in it is still fun on flat ground, but to really get the most out of that you should probably get more than one so that people can collide into each other. I've seen people play games like soccer in a set of these, which is hilariously entertaining, but since we only got one here it felt a little meh until we tried the hill falling thing. I'd recommend getting more than one if you don't have a hill to roll down, but the price can add up pretty quickly.
Highly recommended if you have a hill or the budget for multiple ones!

title: Great, but be careful...
text:
This is a wonderful toy for my boys (and me!). The fact that it is shaped like a rocket is icing on the cake. The launcher shoots balls straight up, sort of like a virtual ball T, unlike pitching machines which throw the ball towards you as from a mound. This system works well enough and it was fun to hit with the included plastic bat (a real bat would send them too far, this is for miniature playing- dare I say, one could even play this indoors if you have enough room and nothing delicate sitting out). The caveat, however, is that there is no safety before it shoots the ball straight up. My younger son who just turned 2 wanted to fetch and reload the balls for his older brother, and when it didn't pop up right away, went to go peek into the hole to see if the ball was there or not. Luckily I saw him and grabbed him away just as the POP of the launcher almost launched a ball into his little face. I can't really fault the product with this too much, I mean, baseball already has tons to keep a toddler away from (swinging bats and flying balls), so really I shouldn't have let him get that close anyway. Just remember to keep an eye on younger kids around this thing.
The other caveat is that we seem to have lost some balls already, and from a search here it looks like you may not be able to find replacements so easily that fit. So, be careful not to lose any.

title: Magnets are FUN!
text:
When I initially got this, I expected only my younger child to be interested in the experiments. However her older siblings actually came and started joining in - because honestly, who can resist playing with magnets?
There are so many cool things these do, from magnetic attraction to poles and repulsion. This is not only fun, but it will give kids the real-world understanding of how magnetism works in a way that can only be achieved with hands on experience.
Very highly recommended for parents and teachers, or heck even someone who just likes playing with magnets!

title: Can store your cars and compatible with track systems!
text:
Place the car on the launcher, aim it to the level you want by counting clicks, and FIRE! The car will land on the level of garage you want with perfect precision! Not only is it fun to launch cars through the air, you can actually use the garage to store your cars inside to put them away. You can twist the top to make room for a new car, and when that level is full start filling the next one! So essentially you can be "cleaning up" while playing. That's awesome! When you want them to come out, you can twist the top again to line up the car you want with the exit door, then push the exit trigger to let the car down the track, which can be connected to more standard track and sets.
That last part is very cool because unlike many other hotwheels gimmicky stunt sets, this can actually integrate into your existing track system. See the picture attached where I placed some hotwheels orange track from another set into this one. Now when we want a car to eject, it will go around the track of the garage, and down into the waiting course we made for it.
I did notice that some other Hot Wheels cars we own don't necessarily move around the short bend to exit the garage as well as the stunt cars. In particular, my kids tried some of the classic hot rod collectors' cars we have, and some of them got stuck on the bend. But any cars made for stunt sets seem to handle it fine. I won't detract any stars for this because I've had similar experience with other sets. I think the collectors' cars are more for the collection than the tracks.

title: Great classic red ball
text:
I see there are multiple products being sold under this listing, so I want to clarify my review is for the single red ball. They are similar to the ones I remember using to play dodgeball in school decades ago- a big red textured ball that makes a reverberating "poomf!" sound that seems to almost echo inside the ball when hit or kicked. Brings back memories! Aside from using it for games like elimination and kickball, my kids actually starting using it to replace a volleyball/soccer ball since the younger siblings find real volleyballs too rigid to play without hurting their hands.
I see there are some low reviews claiming the balls didn't hold up and/or appear prematurely worn, but this hasn't been my case. I also notice that many of those reviews are for the 6-ball kit, so perhaps the multi-pack options are of lower quality than the single ball variants. All I can say for certain is ours has been great so far, and exactly what I expected it to be!

title: Messy and hard to clean off
text: Let me start off by admitting that the kids DID have fun playing with it. That's why it deserves at least 3 stars. But it is surprisingly messy for a product that claims to be for kids. They had a really hard time washing it off their hands, and there's a big warning on the package (which we didn't notice until after opening it) that says it may stain fabrics. The paint really easily gets everywhere- we found more of it the day after cleaning it up that we didn't even notice. On that note, the 3D aspect of it is kind of gimmicky at best. You can't really make a three dimensional structure, at most you can make little mountain dollops (as pictured) which take forever to dry. As in, you might need to keep it in a safe place for a couple of days before anyone can touch it. To be fair, they call it "fluffy", which it is. But the marketing would have you believe it can be somehow used to create 3D depth sort of like play-doh, which isn't true. Actually, I think Play-doh would probably have been a better project than this. Easier to clean up, can mix colors and make shapes, and dries into solid 3D shapes. But then again you can't use that to paint a picture as well, which this sort of does. So I guess this is sort of a product in between paint and play-doh. Not really what we were expecting.

title: Well built, cute, and BIG!
text:
This stuffed animal is larger than our 2 year old (which makes it even cuter when he plays with it)! It is constructed very well and seems very durable, which shouldn't be any surprise from a quality brand name like Melissa & Doug.
We used to have a large stuffed animal in the playroom downstairs (from another brand) that started tearing and losing stuffing, so we had to let it go. My kids are very excited that we offered to replace it with this one- it seems like it will hold up better to the wear and tear my kids put them through.

title: Cute, but not what my daughter expected
text:
My daughter has a bottle that she made from another kit a long time ago, but it got left in a bag for an extended time and got moldy, so she was excited to start over with this one!
First, let me say she is not really a fan of Sunny Day (I personally was not even aware of this character before this experience), so someone who is would probably be more enthusiastic about it than she was. She just wanted a water bottle that she "made herself". But to our surprise, a lot of the bottle was already colored- you're just given the ability to decorate parts of the image (the hair, for example). I did not realize this before getting it, and she was kind of disappointed in that.
I suppose if your child is a fan of Sunny and wants to color her hair, this would be a cute project that can also be a water bottle. My daughter still loved it and wants to drink from it whenever she can, but keep a realistic expectation of what it is (and isn't).

title: Hotwheels quality
text: I've heard from collectors that there is some concern about the "exclusive" part here. But I'm not a collector, I'm just a fan. I love Hot Wheels, and have since I was a kid. Aside from the special edition Back to the Future Delorean that I bought years ago and keep on a shelf (fan of Deloreans in general), hot wheels are for racing in tracks in my household, and my kids can get pretty creative with those tracks. We can never have enough vehicles, which is why this product is so excellent- they are each individually boxed so they make great gifts you can give one at a time, or even re-gift and give as presents to others. They are well built, as are all Hot Wheels, and come with the same limited lifetime warranty (not that anyone uses it). As for the exclusivity of it- I don't recall seeing these exact models on shelves before, but I'm not enough of an expert to comment on that part one way or the other.

title: Awesome party game!
text:
We chose the 3' version because we wanted the carrying bag which it seems the larger 4' one does not have. The timing is perfect because we are having a lot of extended family visit, and I have to admit this game is a HIT at a gathering! Unlike a small tabletop game between 2 people, this is large enough that onlookers start rooting and giving their advice, splitting into teams, etc... sort of like the giant arcade versions of connect 4.
The game is simple enough to play (assuming the reader already knows how to play the classic 4-in-a-row game), large pieces get inserted on the top and make a satisfying THUD as they plunk down into place. The bottom border can be removed to let the pieces come crashing out which is also satisfying, and it has a layer of padded material on top of that border so that the game pieces don't smack too hard when they plunk down. The whole thing is built out of solid wood and seems really well built. If you're having a large gathering and want to do something fun, this could be a real crowd pleaser!

title: This is a remake of an older set
text:
I'm far from an expert in Ninjago, but I am aware that there was an earlier Golden Dragon set from around 2013 with a different model number - 70503, whereas this one is 70666. I never owned the earlier model, but from what I've seen of it, it had a larger dragon model with an admittedly cooler looking face. This one seems a bit more subdued, however the additional character pieces are somewhat more updated and cool looking on this one. It still has most of what made the original cool- there are moving pieces that launch projectiles and enough parts to be fun to build and play.
It is a great set in and of its own right, just be aware that if you're looking for the original set from 2013 (pre the Ninjago movie), I'm pretty sure they don't make them anymore.

title: More affordable knock off of Magnet Tiles
text:
My kids love Magnet Tiles, but the official ones are too pricey. We've been using clones and these fit right in with them. In the picture you can see they have a diamond shape in the plastic to reinforce and give it extra strength, whereas the other magnet tile clones we own have triangles or grid patterns to reinforce the structure. But either way, they work the same and are compatible with each other. In the second picture you can see them being used interchangeably with other magnetic tile clone pieces.
Works great, and a fun toy if you want to compliment an existing magnet tile set or start a new one.

title: Go ninja, go ninja-go?
text:
We love legos. My son loves Ninjago. I enjoyed the movie, but honestly don't know much about the show, aside from it being a shameless plug to sell toys. But I don't mind when the toys are this cool! So what's not to love?
The parts here build a sort of spinning top toy that adds another dimension to play, and keeps it really interesting in my opinion. Keep 'em coming, Lego! Great stuff!

title: BIG fun
text:
[[VIDEOID:6988d65358b2a691251302969b1c2fdd]] We own quite a few RC toys in our house, but most of them are of the race car variety. The one I'm reviewing is not only a replica of a famous monster truck, but it is a whopping 1:10 scale model, which means BIG! Most of our other vehicles fall in between the 1:24-1:15 scale size.
It isn't the fastest vehicle, but it makes fun monster truck noises and can effectively climb over other RC cars if you collide at the right angles. Even if you aren't a fan of the classic Monster Truck this is modeled after, it is a hoot to drive around and make big truck noises with.
I can't really do it justice in a written review so I'm including a quick video demo so you can hear and see it.
One thing to note that I couldn't show in the video: Ours came in a box that appears to be set up for a store display (it said "try me", and the remote was wired up to make noises if the buttons are pressed). At first I thought we made a mistake and it was actually a wired toy and not a wireless remote, because there was a ribbon cable that went from the remote into the bottom of the truck, but upon removal we realized it must just be for the "demo mode", and the ribbon actually pulls out with the help of a fingernail or flathead screwdriver. Once the ribbon is removed and batteries are put into the remote, it worked as expected, but there was oddly nothing in the instructions about this and it wasn't immediately obvious.

title: Great for younger kids and easy to drive
text:
As an RC enthusiast household, this is a very fun addition. My youngest (2 years old at the time of this writing) loves the RC toys his older siblings and I play with, but pretty much all of them are too difficult for him to use. He sure does try though, then gets very frustrated when he can't get it to do much of anything.
This toy is perfect- even though it was designed for kids older than him, it is easy enough for him to understand the 2-button layout (one button goes forward, one reverse-while-turning). The idea with this two button control is that he presses the main forward button until it hits something or goes where he doesn't want it to, then press the other button to back up and change the angle, then go again. It doesn't have the precise controls of an adult hobby RC obviously, but to a child who just wants GO and UNDO, this works great!
It also has fun sound effects that he really likes, as well as a removable toy driver (which he calls "Robot", because with the helmet it looks like a toy robot a bit. In fact, he calls the whole thing his robot car). The only thing I don't like about it, however, is that it uses regular AA batteries. All of our other RC toys use rechargeable packs designed for high output and recharging when depleted, because running a motor uses a relatively high amount of amperage for a small battery, and depletes them pretty quickly. With regular alkalines, this toy seems to still be running after nearly a week, but it is clearly slowing down a lot and should probably be changed.
Sure, we could use rechargeable batteries in it, but they actually start with less voltage even when fully charged, so we'd just have to change them more often and get less time at regular speed (if ever) than an alkaline. A week between charges isn't terrible, but it seems more wasteful than our other RC toys and makes me wish it used a rechargeable pack. But otherwise, its a great product for younger fans of remote control toys!

title: For a new generation!
text:
I have to admit, I was pleasantly surprised to see this name again! My daughter loves the old sets and whenever we go to visit my parents, my mom lovingly takes out the vintage sets for my girls to play with. They have asked me why we don't have any at home, and I tell them sadly that they don't seem to make them anymore.
So imagine our collective enthusiasm when I showed them this playset! It has been updated for the new generations, but is just as cute and fun and they truly do love it. Glad to see it back again.

title: FAST and powerful!
text:
[[VIDEOID:9cca81560b20214b5c0638458bc47093]] My kids have quite a few inexpensive RC toys, cars, helicopters, mini drones, etc. But this is different. In fact, on the rear of the box I recall a warning that said "This is not a toy", which should have tipped me off to what I was in for!
This reminds me more of those hobbyist gas-powered RC cars, the kind that feel like they could probably keep up with an actual car if the driver was crazy enough to drive alongside it. It has spring suspension on the wheels which help it climb (and sometimes fly or flip!) over obstacles, it can drift, and it has a truly impressive range from the remote We were still able to drive it from several houses on our block away!
The only thing I don't like about it is how it gets charged. You need to remove the top to access the charging port, and that top is held on by 4 metal clips. Not only are the clips difficult to remove and replace, they are EXTREMELY easy to lose. We thought we lost them a few times already, but eventually they do show up. I know it is only a matter of time before we lose one, then another, etc. I wish there was a way to access the battery port from the rear or bottom of the vehicle so we wouldn't have to remove the entire top to get to it. So removing a star for difficulty in charging, but otherwise this is more fun than anything this size and price range has any business being!

title: Cars AND bath time?! YES!
text: My son who is turning two loves toy cars. He also loves baths, but sometimes he is too busy playing to be interested in taking one. This toy is perfect for him because he can play with it on the floor, then when we tell him it is bath time he can TAKE IT WITH HIM! The cars float like a boat and he loves taking the fronts off and mixing them with the other color (they attach magnetically to mix and match fronts to backs). Very cute and suffice to say he loves them.

title: Points for portability but not really what I expected.
text:
I guess this is good for someone who wants a portable seat with a tray that they can take with them on an outing, but I was more interested in a booster seat to bridge the gap between a high chair and sitting at the table. Our other kids all used one when they were old enough, and it would help make them high enough to join us while also being able to buckle them in for safety.
This one, however, seems really short. Unlike the old boosters we had for our previous kids, these don't really "boost" high enough for our little guy to reach the table. He likes that it is on a regular chair and not his old high chair, but to be honest, at least his old high chair could go high enough to reach the table comfortably without the tray. And speaking of the tray, this one is a very crude design that just bends and snaps over plastic tabs that stick out. They aren't easy to remove with one hand and sometimes it feels almost like the plastic is bending to the point of breaking when you put it on. The one feature I think is kind of cool is the clear plastic tray to put a phone or tablet underneath. That way your little one can see but not touch the device (useful for watching videos). It comes with some coloring sheets which were a nice touch, and some app subscription that I wasn't really interested in but might be useful for some.
All in all, if you want a portable tray chair or live in a small space that doesn't have room for a full sized high chair, this might be something for you. That's honestly probably where all the more positive reviews are coming from. But if you want a BOOSTER, that is, something to make your child high enough to sit at the table (which this advertises it can do), this isn't a great option in my opinion.

title: LOVING these themed Lego kits
text: After building some Lego kits with my son as a bonding experience, he has been asking me to find more "cool" kits he can build himself. This set is great, they have moving parts and spring loaded "weapons". Just be careful, like all Legos, you don't want pieces left around for you to step on. The spring loaded moving part kinds like these are more of a liability in that regard, but I have to admit the finished product looks pretty darn cool!

title: Great for my girls
text: I have daughters 2 years apart in age that adored this set. My son and I were busy building a Star Wars lego set in the other room, and the girls went to town on this one. Plenty of parts for 2 kids to build in tandem and they used the box they built to write notes to each other and hide inside it. Usually Lego play for them means digging into a bin and snapping random bricks together, so this taught them 2 things that I really appreciate: 1) They can follow directions without adult supervision and make something they are proud of, and 2) Legos can be used for real world things like a box to put non-lego things into. Really opens up their imagination beyond playing, and now they want to make other practical Lego creations. Very cool.

title: Legos + Star Wars = AWESOME
text: My son and I are both fans of classic Star Wars and legos. Ok, perhaps I'm more of the Lego fan in the family surprisingly. But this set was a great bonding experience for us to build together. It's a recreation of one of the classic moments from the original film, as shown on the box. My only issue is that once it was built, it felt kind of limited to that one moment. Like, the scene in the film is really only a few seconds long. To be fair, I think it would be cool to keep on my desk at work or something to add some personality, but it isn't the sort of set you'd build and then use your imagination to play with for hours. For that sort of play, you'll probably re-purpose the bricks for something more elaborate anyway. Still, was a fun project and worth it for any fan of Star Wars and Legos.

title: Meh- but the kid likes it, so its a win.
text:
First things first, I've been reviewing a lot of headphones lately. These aren't great sound quality, they don't cancel noise, and aren't very comfortable for me wear. BUT... that's not what they are for! My daughter loves them, they don't get too loud as to damage her ears, I can still get her attention while she's wearing them, and they fit a child's head. Since those are the main things this headset aspires to be, I say it is a success.
The colors are fun and it even has these little paper inserts you can remove and color on (there are some cartoon coloring images for the kids to fill in or they can turn it around and draw on the blank back for a truly custom look). So, 4 stars for a kid's headset that appeals to kids. I would have given it 5 stars if the sound quality were a little better and/or the build quality was higher. But, to be fair there are other headphones that would appeal to people looking for that.

title: So cute and my girls love it!
text: Being a 30-something with a son means I'm no stranger to Legos. But this is the first set I let my little girls open and build themselves, and now I'm kicking myself for not doing this sooner. They love following the directions and building what's on the box, then they take it apart and start re-purposing parts with their imagination. It is a very cute set, with moving hinge pieces and some unique shaped bits that I definitely don't already have in our collection of bricks. I may need to get more sets like these.

title: Awful build quality.
text: These work great out of the box, and it IS clever how it gets packed into a soda-can sized plastic tube, but I wish they were made to a higher spec. These break within hours of getting them, and even appear used already (LED light assembly had one that was out in the tail, the antennae connection was snapped off inside, and the paint appears smeared and/or chipped). I thought maybe I had gotten a defective unit or returned item, but it turns out I got a replacement and it was SAME ISSUE. I think these are just built poorly. Its a shame because the idea of a remote controlled car the size of a hotwheels is super cool and fun! But even if you get one that works most of the way out of the box, it'll only take a few minutes of driving before the wheels start having trouble sending it into a perpetual 360 degree spin instead of going in a straight line (riding the steering button sometimes helps it go in a straight line again). I had similar issues with Pocket Racers, I thought maybe these would be better but it seems all of these tiny RC cars are just built poorly. I wish someone made good ones even if they have to cost more. Very disappointed, my son was really set on one of these.

title: Fun to fly, just be careful not to treat it roughly
text:
We're on an RC kick here in my house, and we love these! As I write this, there are about 4 remote controls on my living room couch for various things (drones, RC cars, helicopters, etc) that my kids left out. Helps that my living room has 18 foot cathedral ceilings!
Only problem is, the charging port is delicate on this style of helicopter. This was actually bought to replace a previous one that had the charging port go bad. I wish you could just replace the battery instead of relying on the wonky charging port, but for the price I'm happy with another one for now. Had a talk with the kids about being careful unplugging when finished charging, and hopefully it will last longer this time.

title: My kids love Mastermind, but I'm so glad I found this ...
text: My kids love Mastermind, but I'm so glad I found this magnetic version. Not only is it a fraction of the price of the big name brand, the magnetic pieces means you can leave the game and resume later, knowing that every piece is exactly where you left it off. Very happy with this!

title: This pillow is hand washable and dried like new within hours
text:
I bought this as part of a gift to my wife on Mother's Day- the plan was to have our kids sign their names on the back in permanent ink. To my surprise, one of my younger kids decided to take it upon herself to get out her marker set AND DECORATE THE WHOLE THING! I thought it was ruined, regular washable markers littered all over the thing, and the ink would run onto your hand if touched. But, turns out, this pillow is hand washable and dried like new within hours. I couldn't believe how well it came out, my wife had no idea that it happened!
Suffice it to say, this pillow has exceeded my expectations. After all that, it still came out great, is surprisingly soft and comfortable and everyone loves it!

I definitely recommend it for out doors adventures. It encourages the kids to really look at what's around them, so they can find every texture and size on the cards.

title: Predictable roll
text: The toy weazel is soft to the touch and looks cute. The ball is sturdy and moves for a long time on batteries without too much noise. The problem is the ball usually rolls in a predictable, small, circle that my pet finds more annoying than fun. I think if there was some kind of setting to make the ball move in random directions, my pet would keep interest.

title: Vibrant Colors
text:
So, I was a little worried about buying this puzzle. There were no reviews for it yet and I'm the type to only buy things online that have been thoroughly reviewed. However, I loved the picture and low puzzle piece count of 300. Therefore, I took a chance on this product and, so far, I like what I see.

As described by the product page, this puzzle does not come in a large box with a fancy picture on the front. The box is small, white, and everything fits snuggly inside. What it does come with, however, is a very strikingly beautiful and high quality printed picture that's about 7.75" x 5.5". The downside of this small box is that the picture is too wide to fit inside. Therefore, it was folded two ways which left creases (see images). Also, although the image is beautiful, the paper it's printed on is definitely not card stock. It feels like normal printed paper with a semi-glossy top sheen. In all, the picture isn't the best but it's no where near the worst. I really appreciate that the image is printed so well (not fuzzy, high contrast, bright colors, etc) and I really like the slight gloss.

The puzzle pieces also look to be good quality. The pieces a very bright and look as beautifully printed as the image with the same glossy finish (Yay!). The wood looks tough and there doesn't seem to be any broken pieces. The bag has a little saw dust here and there but it's nothing than can't be gently wiped away (There is no large collection of saw dust in the bag which is quite nice to see). The pieces are cut very well with no splinters. Also, there are no letters on the back, something I think is a definitely plus because I think letters can be distracting.

In conclusion, I definitely think I made a good choice by buying this puzzle. I was worried the picture would be fuzzy, but the image and colors look so vibrant. The puzzle is a gift for my mom on Mother's Day I think she'll like it. <3

title: Terrible packaging but Beautiful Puzzle
text:
This puzzle was shipped fast to my house and the colors are gorgeous. The puzzle itself is very nice quality.

However:

1. There is no puzzle box. Nothing. Just some cheap, plastic bag. Mine was coming apart at the seams. Luckily, it arrived with all my pieces.

2. The provided picture is a small, 6.5"x4.5" print on cheap, flimsy paper (NOT laminated and, therefore, prone to stains and tears)

3. The puzzle arrives in 4 large pieces. This is nice because you get instant verification that you have all the pieces. This is NOT nice when you realize that you will have to break apart all 500 pieces yourself.

Considering the time and materials that was saved on the manufacturer's side, I feel like this puzzle was very overpriced.

This was a gift for my mom, but, in my opinion, this puzzle was no where near gift-ready. I went and bought a box to put the pieces in and a small picture frame for the puzzle picture. I labeled the box, colored it, and gave it to my mom. She loved it.

If you are ok with the three points I mentioned above, then I still suggest buying this puzzle. The puzzle is very beautiful with thick pieces and a nice finished size. The Moana picture is cute. The packaging, however, is very skimpy.
